column1: If you want to know more about developing a business model for a startup and/or setting up your own venture, the Entrepreneurial Lab course is for you. Within an intense and hand-on experiential approach, the Entrepreneurial Lab course allows you exploring a business opportunity with your team and testing its potential value.

This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the role, the analytics, and the process of business planning that leads to the successful creation of new ventures. Above all, students will be responsible to develop their own professional networks. As it’s a hands-on course, you will learn about business modelling, how to refine opportunities, analyse feasibility, financial planning, and organisational implementation. You will write a weekly blog and a business report and pitch your idea to a jury of experts. In previous years our students launched successful new businesses, including Senz Umbrellas, Symbid and Yoursurprise.com.

In this Minor, students learn how entrepreneurs create business opportunities and transform them into successful start-ups and sustainable businesses. You experience what it takes to become an entrepreneur by developing your own business idea in a team of students, under the guidance of expert coaches. We believe that entrepreneurship is not only reserved for exceptional visionary people such as Steve Jobs, Richard Branson and Elon Musk, but that everyone can be an entrepreneur, provided they are motivated and know where to start. We provide students with a toolbox that helps them to get started. You will learn and practice an effectual and lean approach to creating new ventures. This approach is based on action-oriented core principles that underlie the decision-making approach and behaviour of expert entrepreneurs. The emphasis is not on writing a business plan but on testing ideas in the market and building real partnerships with relevant stakeholders such as customers, suppliers and investors.

The entrepreneurial adventure in this Minor concludes with a pitch event where student teams present their business idea and achievements to a panel of experts. For this course, there is intense collaboration with the Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship (ECE), i.e., the Rotterdam knowledge hub that supports the teaching staff of the Minor with their expertise and network of entrepreneurs within the Rotterdam area. For more information, see: http://ece.nl.

column2: The major part of this Minor is the Core Module where you learn how to get started and develop entrepreneurial skills (such as pitching, financial bootstrapping and design thinking). Next to the Core Module, students choose one out of two elective modules that help them to develop their entrepreneurial knowledge and skills in a specific area: Entrepreneurial Marketing or Entrepreneurial Finance. These electives focus on (1) marketing challenges and how entrepreneurs with limited budgets reach, communicate and co-develop with their customers; and (2) unique financial issues related to entrepreneurial firms and the (dis)advantages of various sources of financing, respectively.

column1: In this course the focus is on understanding and developing entrepreneurial behavior, i.e., mainly involving the identification and exploitation of (new) opportunities. Entrepreneurial behavior may be motivated by economic or social value creation, and can take place within companies or organizations, or via starting up an own business. The course consists of two main (building) blocks. The modules in Block 7 are focused on learning ‘about’ entrepreneurship and entrepreneurial behavior from an academic perspective, whereas the modules in Block 8 have a hands-on approach and are focused on experiencing entrepreneurial behavior yourself.
In this block we will use different teaching methods to illustrate entrepreneurship from an academic perspective. Here we will zoom in on 4 key questions:

column2: • Which types of entrepreneurs are there? (Module 2)
• How do entrepreneurs successfully build their ventures? (Module 4)

column1: Each module addresses the question from different angles and uses a variety of different methods: the modules consist of knowledge clips, tutorials, and academic literature. The prescribed literature will be presented to you and discussed in the knowledge clips by the teachers (available online via Canvas). The tutorials offer room to discuss the literature in an interactive way to increase knowledge, understanding and insight gained from the knowledge clips.

Before tutorial 3 you need to submit an assignment about a course-related movie or documentary on the topic of entrepreneurship. In this assignment students apply the knowledge from the literature and tutorials and reflect on the literature based on the storyline in the movie.

The Entrepreneurship course is very hands-on. This means that you will not only learn about entrepreneurship, but that you will also experience what it means to be(come) one. In Block 7 you will work on a business case to identify an entrepreneurial opportunity for this year’s case company, which will be introduced to you during the kick-off lecture in Block 7. In Block 8 you will then dream up and create your own start-up in a team of students during the “RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge”.

Block 8 will be dedicated to the RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge. To support this challenge, tutorials and feedback sessions by (alumni) entrepreneurs will be focused on providing input for developing a value proposition and creating a business model. In an entrepreneurial way, you will be introduced to important milestones that can ultimately lead to the start of a successful own business.

In tutorial 5, teams of 5 students will be formed for the RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge. These student teams are challenged to develop a business model for a company and, if possible, bring it to the market. The challenge is to (1) arrive at an innovative business model based on the Lean Startup method, (2) actively apply knowledge from the tutorials, and (3) work creatively. The business model will be judged based on the criteria of desirability, feasibility, viability & innovativeness:

column2: • Desirability (the extent to which customers / buyers are actually interested in the value proposition offered)
• Feasibility (the extent to which the business model can actually be implemented as described)
• Viability (the degree to which it is realistic that the proposed business model will actually achieve its goals)
• Innovativeness (the degree to which the business model is new, original and creative).

column1: For each of these dimensions, the stronger the evidence provided and the more thorough the validation, the better the score.
Block 8 will be concluded with a team report and presentation. The best teams will be selected and invited to pitch during the final event, where they compete for a great prize.

Any form of social and economic value creation is permitted, as long as it is (1) legal, (2) does not damage the reputation of the Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University and (3) is based on a clear earnings model and business model.

column1: In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and practice. Entrepreneurship is all about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. In this course students will focus on three views of entrepreneurship theory: entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.  Students will also develop that mind-set by practically exploring the initial stages of entrepreneurial process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models by following lean canvas principles. This course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business venture and presenting it in front of a jury from Entrepreneurship Center of Erasmus (ECE).

column1: During this course we will address the role of entrepreneurship within media markets. We will look at this issue from two angles: entrepreneurship from the perspective of the challenger start-up   company and entrepreneurship within existing media firms. We will discuss literature on entrepreneurship and business model innovation and apply these insights to media related case studies. Furthermore, we will discuss how entrepreneurial principles are applied to media endeavors with not-for-profit social objectives. We will address questions such as: how to identify new market opportunity or social opportunities,  how to find competitive advantage in a media market, how to move from idea to execution and how to scale up and manage growth.
In line with the entrepreneurial focus of this course, students are required to write a business plan

for a media-related startup and develop a new value proposition for an existing company. During this process students will experience the valuable contribution of scientific inquiry and insights for the development of new products and services. Students are also required to pitch their business idea and will receive presentation training during the course.

As entrepreneurship is the theme of the course, we will invite several professionals from the media industry to discuss their entrepreneurial endeavors. We will also try to arrange having company visits (the dates for these visits might be at a different time than regular classes). Students are also encouraged to organize this themselves.

column1: This focus area seminar aims to understand environmental protest culture on a theoretical level and to explore the relevance of mass media and different social media platforms for protest communication.

We will examine different case studies of environmental protest campaigns since the 1960s and consider the roles different types of media played in their developments. In this context, we will discuss how questions of globalization, consumption, social injustice, inequality, and environmental protest are intertwined and how as well as why these different issues gain and lose relevance over time.

As in recent years, environmental activism engages in new ways of disrupting visual routines and situations of everyday life, the role of social media in the circulation of videos and images of single protest actions will be questioned in particular to understand how they achieve wide reach and visibility.

The use of ritual as well as visuality and framing in past and current cases of environmental protests will be analysed and it will be examined, whether a protest habitus can be observed and how communicative actions in environmental protest culture can be described. We will study sociological concepts of knowledge and social systems and transfer them to exemplary case studies to grasp how environmental protest actions operate on the level of symbol and meaning and thereby challenge understandings of different aspects of everyday life.

column1: Entering the 21st century, climate change, globalization, inequality, and rural-to-urban migration have created conditions conducive to emerging infectious diseases and food production challenges. Epidemics and famine are yet to be consigned to the past, and this is worrying given that the World Health Organization has expressed concerns that the social and economic impact of both can be massive. However, measuring their effects is not straightforward. Can history provide new insights by offering a temporal perspective?

By comparing traumatic events such as Great European Famine of 1315-17, the ‘Columbian Exchange’ diseases of American colonization, the worldwide influenza pandemic of 1918-20, and the Great Leap Forward Famine in China of 1958-62, can we understand more about diseases today such as Ebola or famines in East Africa, Syria and Yemen? Although the past may be a ‘foreign country’, we shall see that there are many points of continuity and similarity.

Students will learn the causes and characteristics of epidemics and famines, and their effects on development and welfare, social (dis)order, gender inequalities, public health, and their relationship with climate change. We also consider how epidemics and famines have been represented and remembered by surviving generations, and consider controversies over ‘who is to blame’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will explain the causes, characteristics and consequences of epidemic diseases and famines throughout history.
• Students will recognize that the outcomes from epidemics and famines could be very different across time, region, and outbreak, and offer explanations.
• Students will draw links between the pre-industrial past, the recent past, and contemporary developments, and show the value of a historical approach to epidemics and famines.

column1: What does it mean to be a philosopher today? What can we as philosophers contribute to pressing debates on societal issues? Shall we try to offer solutions or rather ask the right questions? What can we learn from the philosophical tradition in current crisis situations?

This course aims to promote philosophical reflection on contemporary challenges through exploring various dilemmas and possible responses, We will examine key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’ such as the climate crisis and the crisis of truth and trust in politics. We will discuss the specific function and value of a philosophical approach to these challenges, the relation between descriptive and normative statements in contemporary debates, the relation between philosophy and politics and the role of the philosopher in society.

column1: Ethical Aspects of Economics is a course about topics at the intersection of ethics and economics. You will be introduced to several contemporary topics in this area and given the opportunity to write on issues that you find particularly interesting.

The course will begin with two economic concepts with great importance for contemporary ethics: efficiency and utility. Next, we look at ethical aspects of research in economics. We then turn to debates over distributive justice: how should the resources produced in the economy be distributed? Finally, we dive into the arguments concerning the ethical limits of markets.</body>

column1: <body>This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality or the role and limits of the market in addressing environmental degradation and climate change.</body>

column1: <body>The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.

column2: • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/105237,2022,Ethics in Econometrics,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. JJ Vromen', 'prof.dr. PHBF Franses']",,"Inhoud

Econometricians use methods and techniques drawn from mathematics and statistics to address economic issues and questions. These questions can concern the macroeconomy, finance, microeconomic issues, labor, and various business economic settings. Typically, econometricians examine economic theories, create forecasts, develop multiple scenarios, propose optimal decisions, or evaluate policies. When the examinations are substantially novel and relevant to share with academics, the research findings can be published in academic literature, where other econometricians judge the merits of the work. In many other settings, however, the studies end up in an advice to an end user who can use the forecasts, who decides on the continuation or a change of the policy, who implements a proposed decision, or who picks one of the scenarios for making further plans.

It is important to recognize that such an end user rarely is an econometrician too. An end user can for example be an employee (top level or middle level) in a government, in a company, or in a bank. This implies that rarely an end user can fully grasp every single step that an econometrician has set when creating the product. At the same time, it is often also not possible to present every single step, and perhaps it is also not instrumental for the end user’s intentions. This means that the end user must trust that the econometrician made the right choices during the analysis.

There are various ethical guidelines around, and these usually concern honesty related to for example data cleaning (from raw data to the data to be analyzed), estimation methods, decisions based on statistical inference, trial and error and the reporting. Basically, these guidelines should establish that the final product can be reproduced when a list of choices and also the programming code is provided.

In this course we will initially discuss these guidelines but after that, in the main content of the course, we will address more specific ethical issues that follow from the fact that there is a knowledge asymmetry between the end user and the econometrician. Loosely said, even when the standard ethical guidelines are obeyed, it is still possible to provide an advice that meets a specific request of an end user. For example, it is not difficult to create a forecast that comes close to a desired target of an end user.

This course provides a range of cases where the knowledge asymmetry can be exploited intentionally, even though reproduction still is possible. There are cases where the result crucially depends on a single observation, cases where the statistical test is performed such that an outcome is manipulated, and for example cases where initial configurations dominate the result, even though it is very difficult to see.

This courses uses knowledge of FEB22015(X) Academic Skills and FEB22009(X) Introductory Seminar Case Studies Econometrics and Operations Research, and is required for each major seminar and the bachelor thesis.
General aspects of ethics (lecturer from ESPhil)
General aspects of ethics in econometric academic research and application
Specific aspects of the ethics of econometrics which are caused by knowledge asymmetry between model builder/forecaster (the adviser) and the advisee.

column1: Welke rol spelen emoties in de morele oordeelsvorming van mensen? Zijn emoties constitutief voor de morele positie die mensen innemen of zijn het stoorzenders die een redelijke oordeelsvorming in de weg staan? En: wat zijn emoties? Zijn emoties louter gevoelens en is een moreel oordeel daarom altijd de expressie van een bepaald gevoel? Of zijn emoties ook te beschouwen als cognitieve mentale toestanden die ons informatie verschaffen over onszelf en over de wereld om ons heen? Ter beantwoording van deze vragen zullen we in deze cursus niet alleen de meest actuele moraalfilosofische debatten over ethiek, rationaliteit en emoties bespreken, maar ook te rade gaan bij het hedendaagse moraalwetenschappelijke onderzoek naar de oorsprong en aard van emoties en naar de invloed van emoties bij oordeelsvorming (o.m. werk van Frans de Waal, Jonathan Haidt en Antonio Damasio). We zullen nadenken over de lichamelijke basis van gevoelens en emoties en dit verbinden met cognitief psychologisch onderzoek naar de onmisbare (en soms misleidende) rol van emoties in het redeneren en het vormen van een standpunt. Vervolgens zullen we discussiëren over wat dit betekent voor de aard en de betrouwbaarheid van evaluatieve oordelen. Een morele stellingname is meer dan de expressie van een gevoel. Maar in welke zin is het meer en anders?
Voor de voltijdstudenten zijn de hoor/werkcolleges verplicht.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Inzicht verkrijgen in de belangrijkste hedendaagse moraalfilosofische en moraalwetenschappelijke visies en debatten over de aard van emoties en over de rol van emoties en redenen in morele oordeelsvorming; het op basis van dit inzicht ontwikkelen van een eigen standpunt ten aanzien van enkele cruciale kwesties in de morele psychologie en meta-ethiek.
Inzicht krijgen in de historisch-filosofische achtergronden  en de actuele betekenis van het enactivisme voor hedendaagse visies op emoties en praktische rationaliteit.
Begrijpen hoe de enactivistische benadering  van  affectiviteit  zich onderscheidt van traditionele cognitivistische en non-cognitivistische  emotietheorieën.

Kunnen uitleggen wat het belang is van ‘embodied emotions’ voor thema’s  binnen de  morele psychologie en ethiek  zoals:  vrije wil & akrasia,  praktische rationaliteit & cognitieve irrationaliteit,  empathie &  intersubjectiviteit, zelfbewustzijn,  zelfbedrog &  immoraliteit.

column1: Ethische dilemma’s doen zich regelmatig voor in de financiële sector. Vooral na de financiële crisis van 2007/08 heeft ethiek in de financiële sector meer aandacht gekregen van wetgevers, toezichthouders en de media. Schandalen zoals Enron, Panama Papers en ING worden vaak besproken in ethische discussies en leiden tot bewustwording in de financiële sector. Toch blijven dergelijke schandalen zich voordoen, wat bijvoorbeeld blijkt uit het schandaal rondom betaaldienstverlener Wirecard en de Mondkapjesdeal. Hoe dienen wij deze problematiek te benaderen? Hoe kunnen klassieke ethische theorieën ons hierbij helpen? Op welke wijze geven ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector invulling aan ethische kaders? Hoe verhoudt ethiek zich tot het voldoen aan wettelijke verplichtingen en het handelen naar waarden en normen?

Het vak Ethiek, duurzaamheid en compliance is voornamelijk gericht op vaardighedenonderwijs. U wordt – al dan niet in groepsverband – de vaardigheden bijgebracht om een wetenschappelijke bijdrage te leveren aan ethische discussies die betrekking hebben op de financiële sector. Daarnaast worden enkele hoorcolleges verzorgd waarin diverse actuele onderwerpen worden aangesneden die in ethische perspectief worden geplaatst. Hierbij kan worden gedacht aan de ethische overweging bij corporate governance, waarbij gedrag en cultuur een aanzienlijke rol speelt. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de ethische implicaties van technologische ontwikkelingen in de financiële sector. Het onderwerp duurzaamheid wordt ook uitvoerig onder de aandacht gebracht met bijzondere aandacht voor de Sustainable Development Goals (SDG’s) van de Verenigde Naties. Voorts wordt stilgestaan bij de wisselwerking tussen compliance en ethiek.

Tijdens het vak wordt getoetst aan de hand van (tussentijdse) vaardighedenopdrachten. Deze opdrachten betreffen achtereenvolgens een debat, een vlog en een schriftelijke groepsopdracht. Het vak heeft geen regulier afsluitend schriftelijk tentamen.

column1: This course has the aim for students to become familiar with different offender types and differentiating these offender types based on their etiology and risk factors. Questions that will be addressed are: ""What risk factors for violence does an offender with a psychopathic personality have?"" and ""which subtypes of offenders with a psychotic disorder can we distinguish on the basis of their background?"" In addition, this course involves using fundamental insights from neuroscience. These insights relate to forensic topics such as the emergence of aggression and antisocial behavior and how different brain networks are associated with psychopathic personality. Questions that will be addressed are: ""How do different processes in the brain contribute to the development of aggression?"" and ""how come that a psychopath feels ‘nothing’?"" But also: ""How can activity in the brain be measured and used in violence risk assessment and management?""

Attention is also paid to the emerging field of science named 'neurolaw'. In court, there is an increase in the use of neuroscientific evidence, for example by giving a court ordered forensic neuropsychological examination of the suspect of a crime. This is also increasingly being used by the defense to reduce the sentence, or even to plea for insanity.</body>

Europe in the World is a Master course for students in the International Public Management and Policy program. This course aims at developing students’ understanding of the activities of the European Union in the world. By the end of the course, the students will be able to understand and theoretically explain the EU’s external action. They will appreciate the difficulties of EU’s foreign action, and will be able to critically appraise the EU’s foreign policy. Students will have improved soft and transferrable skills.

Students in this course will be expected to have covered the basics of international relations theory. This can be done by having passed the course Global Governance in the IMP program, or an alternative program elsewhere (recognized at the discretion of the instructor).

column1: The end of WWII engendered the world’s most far-reaching experiment in international cooperation between sovereign nation states.  European countries embarked on a process of integration which has brought them peace, stability and prosperity. Yet, on the European Union’s 60th anniversary, celebrations were noticeably muted with citizens’ support for European integration flagging. How come?

This course explores the historical, legal, political, and economic background to European integration.  It will elucidate the EU’s unique origins, institutions and competences, and debate its place in the world and its relationship to member states. The course sets out to provide the theoretical foundations to critically discuss questions on EU governance, key policy areas, crises and reforms, and to contemplate the EU’s future.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After completing the course, you should be able to:

column2: • Understand the origins and evolution of European integration;
• Assess the political and economic motives of member states to join the European Union;

• Explain the necessary conditions for the transition from constitutional right to international right, as stated by Immanuel Kant in Toward Perpetual Peace (1795), and use this to evaluate the feasibility of the idea of a politically integrated Europe;
• Analyze and reproduce the arguments of Hegel against Kant's idea of global/European perpetual peace;
• Understand the institutional structure and the legal system of the EU, as well as its competences and the limitations thereof;
• Understand the economics behind monetary integration and assess the recent crisis in the Eurozone and potential solutions;
• Apply concepts of sovereignty to the EU in keeping with the latter's political form;
• Examine the European Union’s relations with the outside world;
• Articulate an informed view about current debates on the EU.

Conceptualising Union health competences, the main focus is on Article 168 TFEU. Though understandable, this is however not the entire story. Other legal bases have also been lawfully applied to ensure a high level of health protection (eg, free movement provisions, consumer and environmental protection, social policy, competition policy, etc). For instance, under the consumer protection policy, the general product safety directive (2001/95/EC) established general safety requirements for all consumer products, including medical devices. Combined with the ‘horizontal’ liability directive for defective products (89/374/EEC), both directives are aimed to protect consumers’ (patients’) health against defective products. Additionally, Union social and employment law - aimed at protecting workers and fighting discrimination - had some unintended consequences in health care settings. A clear example is the Working Time Directive’s applicability to medical professionals, which it is claimed has hampered the planning and organization of medical care. Furthermore, the coordination of social security law, the mutual recognition of diplomas of regulated health professions, combined with the harmonization of pharmaceutical law, as well as the impact of European competition law, have a clear health dimension. At the same time we will be confronted with new challenges since the Union is becoming increasingly involved in human rights and health care. The recently endorsed EU Charter of Fundamental Rights and newly established Human Rights Agency may influence EU law on health and health care in the member states. For instance, courts may consider the Charter as the basis of judicial review of the activities of EU institutions. Relevant rights may include the right to life, equal access to health care, human integrity, and informed consent.
Minimum number of participants: 5 pp
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

This course will contribute to promote excellence in teaching and equip students with knowledge of European integration and health law. So far, a separate course on EU integration and health law covering a full range of health (related) topics on European integration is missing. Instead, the fragmented legal approach only addresses certain elements of EU law and health. By developing an extensive and unique teaching program this course will focus on the entire spectrum of EU health law, enabling teachers and students to invest in a relatively unknown area of European integration.

On completion of the course the participant will have a broad knowledge within the EU legal framework. Furthermore, the course will enable participants to understand, apply and analyse EU health legislation, related to relevant cases/topics, more specific this course aims at:
- Increasing new knowledge of the European legal framework on EU health law
- The student will be able to identify, analyse and understand contemporary legal problems and dilemmas in EU health law, and apply this knowledge on similar issues
- The student will be able to formulate relevant legal arguments in the EU health legal debate,
- Encouraging students to develop competence in communication skills,
- The student will be able to analyse and summarize the case law of the EU Court of Justice on health integration issues,
- The student will be able to apply the acquired knowledge in writing an academic legal paper on European integration and health law,

- Promoting innovation in teaching. The innovative teaching method (mix of various teaching methods, student-centred approach and combination of enhancing knowledge and skills) combined with applied (digital) tools stimulate a more problem-solving learning process, therefore fostering new teaching methods and technologies which contributes to enhance communication skills and further understanding of this part of European integration.

column1: In recent decades, there has been a rapidly increasing influence of European Union law on more and more areas of national law. Because of this development, people often speak of the progressive 'Europeanization' of different parts of the national legal systems of the Member States of the EU. Virtually all jurisdictions are affected by EU law, which means that the developments in EU law have a major impact not only on the functioning of the national legal jurisdiction and judicial organization, but also on the daily lives of ordinary citizens.

Building on the students’ existing knowledge about the basic principles of EU law and the institutional framework of the EU, the second-year course ‘European Union Law’ goes beyond the basics of the EU’s construct. In particular, the course focuses on the substantive law of the EU. Students will gain an understanding of the internal market and the four fundamental freedoms, the system of legal protection in the EU, EU competition law, as well as Brexit.

column1: This course analyses the European Union as a political system. Rather than just describing the various political actors and formal and informal decision-making procedures, the course aims at a higher level of understanding by applying theories based on institutional rational choice to the various facets of the EU. The basic idea is that political outcomes are the result of actor preferences and institutions (as rules of the game). Equipped with this approach we will analyse among other things, executive politics, legislative politics, interest group politics, and policy making in a variety of areas.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: After completion of this course, students are able to:
• describe the composition, tasks, internal structure and formal decision-making role of European Commission, the Council of Ministers, the European Parliament, and the European Court of Justice;
• describe the main issues and explain the developments of the EU’s regulatory policies, expenditure policies (budget), and interior policies;

• define and explain central concepts of rational choice-informed political science theories, such as principal agent theories and coalition-formation theory and to describe the assumptions and hypotheses of these theories;
• apply rational-choice informed political science theories to executive politics, legislative politics, interest groups politics, regulatory policies, expenditure policies and interior policies;

column1: Een van de redenen voor de Europese toenadering en de totstandkoming van het Verdrag betreffende (de werking van) de Europese Unie is het streven van de lidstaten om te komen tot een interne, markt zonder fiscale belemmeringen, beperkingen of distorsies. Hierdoor moeten onder andere ondernemingen in staat worden gesteld om zich beter aan te passen aan de interne markt, hun productiviteit te vergroten en hun concurrentiepositie op de internationale markt te versterken. Tijdens dit vak wordt geanalyseerd hoe lidstaten deze economische voorspoed kunnen bereiken zonder oneerlijke fiscale concurrentie. Naast de positieve Europese integratie - de regelgeving - wordt ruimschoots aandacht besteed aan de negatieve integratie, de arresten die door het Hof van Justitie worden gewezen.
Het vak bevat o.a. de volgende onderwerpen:

column2: • Bespreking van de verkeersvrijheden in het VwEU

column1: <body>De doorwerking van het internationale recht op het Nederlandse arbeidsrechtelijke rechtssysteem zal worden besproken. Daarnaast maakt met name het Europees recht het relatief eenvoudig dat een werknemer vanuit Nederland elders in de EU te werk wordt gesteld en vice versa. De regels die hierbij gelden en de problemen die hierdoor kunnen ontstaan worden besproken. Vraagstukken die worden behandeld zijn onder meer: welke fundamentele vrijheden staan de werkgever en de werknemer ter beschikking, hoe verhouden deze vrijheden zich met arbeidsrechtelijke beginselen en rechten, welk recht is van toepassing op de internationale arbeidsovereenkomst en welke rechter is bevoegd bij een geschil. Daarnaast zullen enkele aanpalende actuele onderwerpen worden besproken.</body>

Evolution is such a crucial discipline of modern biology that, in 1973, evolutionary biologist Theodosius Dobzhansky wrote: ""nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution"". In this course, a comprehensive introduction to the fascination field of evolutionary biology will be presented. Topics that will be covered include: the origin of abiotic and cellular life, the theory of evolution by natural selection (descent with modification), concepts of fitness and adaptation, the genetic and developmental basis of evolutionary change, micro- and macroevolution, speciation and extinction, elementary population genetics, palaeontology, and human evolution.

column1: In an infinite population setting, we will learn to use static equilibrium concepts (such as the evolutionary stable strategy), dynamic concepts (such as the replicator dynamics), and we will learn what the relation is between these. In a finite population setting, we will learn what the Moran process is, and get accustomed to evolutionary graph theory.

In order to explain the evolution of prosocial behaviour, we will then apply these evolutionary dynamics and stability concepts to settings with population structure (which then leads to kin selection and/or group selection), repetition (which can lead to the evolution of reciprocity), and partner choice/sexual selection (and its relation to signaling in economic theory). We will also look at subgame perfect equilibria in games where commitment to ""rationally irrational"" behaviour (such as altruism or vengefulness) can have an evolutionary advantage.
We will consider how these predictions can be tested, in and outside the lab, and discuss parts of the empirical literature with each other.

column1: Experiments are an increasingly important tool in economics. They are, for instance, used to understand why financial investors spend too little on stocks, why consumers are reluctant to change brands, and in the analysis of labor market decisions. This course deals with the following questions:

column2: • Why are experiments such a powerful tool to discover the causal effect of a treatment?
• Why should incentives be given in economic experiments work? Do they always work?
• What kind of statistical analyses are needed for experimental data?
• What is the optimal sample size to discover the causal effect of interest?
• Are results found in the laboratory predictive of behavior in the real world?
• How can we test lab-field generalizability by means of field experiments?
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand why randomization is crucial to gather causal inferences of behaviour.
• Understand why economists use incentives in experiments.
• Understand why non-parametric tests are needed to analyze data gathered in experiments.
• Understand why it is sometimes important, and sometimes not important that results from laboratory experiments generalize to other 'real world' settings.
• Know how many indepedent observations one can get out of an experiment.
• Be able to apply some power calculations.
• Be able to come up with an experimental design and derive hypotheses.

Experimental Economics studies economic behavior in a controlled, laboratory or field environment. This course teaches the student how to design an experiment aimed at answering a self-developed research question. In addition, it gives an overview of recent trends in Experimental Economics. The course will focus on a set of recent experimental papers and on experimental designs developed by the students. Each student is expected to actively participate in class by discussing selected papers and to develop and present his or her own experimental design.
Each student is expected to actively participate in classes and to develop an experimental design of his or her own.

column1: The course is built on three pillars: Testing research ideas with clean and rigorous experimental designs, applying the appropriate statistical techniques necessary to analyse these designs, and properly interpreting the implications of the observed results in light of the study design and research question. Topics include: causal inference, experimental designs (factorial designs, within- vs. between-subject designs, mixed designs), validity of designs (internal, external, criterion-related, and construct validities), experimental caveats (demand characteristics, confounds, experimenter expectancy, checks, measurement order, control variables), applying statistics to experimental designs (e.g., simple effects, simple slopes, contrasts, outliers, statistical power, simple mediation, moderated mediation, mediated moderation), data visualization, and scientific integrity (researcher degrees of freedom, questionable research practices, transparency, p-hacking)

We will examine these topics from the perspective of an applied behavioural researcher (with examples from fields such as marketing, organizational behaviour, economics, and psychology). Our focus is thus very practical—to help you overcome any issues that might arise in designing and conducting your experiment, analysing your data, writing up your results, and getting your paper published. An intermediate proficiency in a programming language (preferably R) is strongly encouraged for this class.
As in previous years, we may be able to collect data in the Erasmus Behavioural Lab.

column1: In XP, student teams research philosophical educational challenges from primary school to university, then build educational interventions to address this. To support the projects, an Education Track provides broad philosophical training and a Reflection Track grounds students’ learning through journaling, peer-reflection and workshops. XP premises that education is transdisciplinary: multiple disciplines constitute its contents, interdisciplinary angles feed its processes, while education gives meaning to undisciplined experiences of the world. XP provides a five-level structure for understanding this transdisciplinary whole.

In the Education Track, students encounter problem-based learning, embodied learning, jigsawing, object-based learning, and design-based learning. The track also offers lectures as a safe space for students to discover new philosophical approaches with experts.

The Project Track forms the backbone of XP. Under the guidance of a project supervisor, student teams analyse a real-world education problem in a primary, secondary or tertiary education with a methodology of their choosing, then devise a relevant educational intervention that follows appropriate education design principles, offers answers to their research problem, and can lead to implementation.
The Reflection Track accompanies the Project and Education Tracks in a step-by-step build-up, consisting in:

column2: • Two workshops: one focused on cognitive and individual reflection, the other on group and societal reflection.
• An Articulated Learning Reflection, drawing a learning arc based on student diaries.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Students will demonstrate understanding of key thinkers upon whose work the biggest educational innovations of the 20th & 21st century were based.
• Students will analyse classroom experiments from around the world as inspiration for their own project design.

• Students will identify the rationale behind and practice learning with problem-based learning, embodied learning, jigsawing, case-based learning, closed reading, object-based learning and design-based learning.
• Students will make personal learning goals and measure progress on those goals throughout their learning journey.
• Students will reflect on their own learning and practice through a comprehensive reflection track.
• Students will apply their theoretical knowledge to an educational case study.
• Students will practice working in a problem-oriented project work environment, including group collaboration skills.

• Students will design an educational innovation in response to a social problem in primary, secondary or tertiary education that intervenes appropriately at the cognitive, individual, group, society and global levels.

column1: Course content is organized into seven modules covering the following topics:

column2: • Introduction to Causal Inference—Overview of the course, motivating questions about causes and effects, and the challenges of measuring effects from data
• Potential Outcomes Model—A framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you want to measure and works backward from that

• Graphical Models—Another framework for measuring causal effects from observational data or experiments that begins with what you are willing to assume about the world (and what you can measure) and works forward from that

• Randomized Experiments and Hypothesis Tests—Sampling from a population and random assignment to different treatments are powerful tools for measuring causal effects. Hypothesis tests provide a way to quantify how likely our results are due to these sources of randomness.

• Confounders and heterogeneity—The world is messy. Variables that are correlated with causes and effects can help or hinder our ability to measure causal effects for the entire population or for subsets of the population
• Matching and Regression Estimators—Introduction to typical methods for estimating causal effects

• Challenges to Causal Inference—If we send an email to a customer, they may or may not use that coupon on their next purchase. Here we discuss tools for inference when some people don’t do what we expect them to do.
• Prior to the lecture, you will read the assigned material.

• After reading the material, and before the lecture, you complete a assignment via Canvas to test your comprehension of the material. You can refer to the reading as you complete the assessment. You can also post questions and comments to the discussion board on Canvas, and I will use these posts to determine which material needs more emphasis during the lectures
• During the lecture, we will review material covered by the assigned reading, focusing on what was less clear to most students. We will work through examples, both as a class and in small groups.
• After the lecture, you apply what you’ve learned while completing longer problem sets.
<style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand and differentiate between statistical concepts such as correlation, conditional independence, and likelihood; and causal concepts such as randomization, confounding, and exogeneity
• Express causal relationships among data using Pearl’s graphical framework, and counterfactual quantities of interest using Rubin’s potential outcomes framework
• Derive conditions under which causal relationships can be estimated from data
• Design experiments to measure causal effects
• Simulate outcomes corresponding with an assumed causal model, and use these simulated outcomes to predict the precision of empirical estimates of causal effects
• Think critically about the ethical consequences of performing randomized experiments, and of making causal claims

This course takes an in-depth look at the African continent from African Union (AU) Agenda 2063 the United Nations (UN) Agenda 2030-related perspectives and interweaves sustainable approaches from multiple disciplines.

A flipped classroom guided self-study (1 ECs) in the first week introduces and increases an understanding of the AU and UN agendas. In the following six weeks, three modules will be presented by the participating faculties and institutions through interactive seminars and presentations that stimulate collaboration and knowledge sharing.
Module I: Economies - EUR (3 ECs) explores African socio-economic realities and partnering opportunities in context of SDGs 8 – 10, 12 & 17;
Module II: Resources & Infrastructure - TUD (3 ECs) explores available resources and infrastructure in Africa in context of SDGs 6-7, 11, & 13 -15;
Module III: Social Dynamics - LU (3 ECs) explores African socio-developmental realities in context of SDGs 1 -5 & 16.
The course concludes with an integration discussion and a one-day conference during which students present their group reports on regional challenges & opportunities.

column1: In het vak ‘Externe verslaggeving en accountancy in juridisch perspectief’ wordt vanuit juridisch perspectief aandacht besteed aan de financiële verslaggeving door (beurs)vennootschappen en het interne en externe toezicht dat daarop wordt gehouden. De jaarrekening en de overige stukken die behoren tot de jaarlijkse financiële verslaggeving van (beurs)vennootschappen spelen een belangrijke rol in het economisch verkeer. Deze stukken vormen bijvoorbeeld de basis waarop het bestuur van een vennootschap verantwoording aflegt aan kapitaalverschaffers. Naast de wettelijke vereisten voor de totstandkoming van de jaarrekening, de besluitvorming daaromtrent en de openbaarmaking van de financiële verslaggeving worden ook de mogelijkheden voor uitstel voor het opmaken en de openbaarmaking van deze stukken besproken. Zowel de nationale als Europese wet- en regelgeving (EEG-richtlijnen en de EU-verordening inzake de IFRS), als de niet-wettelijke voorschriften (van de Raad voor de Jaarverslaggeving) passeren daarbij de revue.

De rol van de raad van commissarissen, de accountant, accountantsorganisatie en Autoriteit Financiële Markten komt aan de orde bij het behandelen van het interne en externe toezicht op de totstandkoming van de financiële verslaggeving. Ook de aansprakelijkheid van bestuurders, commissarissen, accountant en accountantsorganisatie wordt behandeld, zowel buiten als in faillissement. Gedurende het vak is ook aandacht voor de mogelijkheden voor belanghebbenden om in rechterlijke procedures naleving van de jaarrekeningvoorschriften af te dwingen.

In het vak is ook ruimschoots aandacht voor actuele ontwikkelingen in de externe verslaggeving zoals duurzaamheidsverslaggeving en digitalisering. Duurzaamheidsverslaggeving is de term die gebruikt wordt voor niet-financiële verslaggeving, de rapportageverplichtingen die voortvloeien uit de Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) vormen hier een voorbeeld van. Ook kan gedacht worden aan de rapportage over VN Sustainability goals. Duurzaamheidsverslaggeving speelt een steeds belangrijkere rol in het economisch verkeer. De wet- en regelgeving voor duurzaamheidsverslaggeving is volop in ontwikkeling en roept interessante vraagstukken op over bijvoorbeeld inrichting, openbaarmaking en controle ervan die gedurende het vak uitgebreid aandacht krijgen.

Verslaggeving heeft op verschillende manieren te maken met de trend van verdergaande digitalisering. Bij de digitale ontwikkelingen rondom verslaggeving kan gedacht worden aan digitaal ondertekenen en deponeren van de jaarrekening maar ook aan de digitale vaststelling van de jaarrekening op de digitale aandeelhoudersvergadering. En ook aandacht voor digitalisering als onderwerp van verslaggeving, als bijv. cybersecurity in de risicoparagraaf, ontbreekt niet.</body>

column1: The Netherlands is well known for its expertise in distribution operations. Many American and Asian multinational companies have established their European logistics centre in the Netherlands, and it is the home base of many logistics service providers and operations. The logistics sector has a big impact on the Dutch economy. Warehousing and distribution are core businesses for many large and smaller firms. While most other courses in the SCM master focus primarily on external logistics and strategic issues, this course focuses on intra logistics (or facility logistics): process design and execution; operations, particularly those within facilities. External and intralogistics are strongly related and interdependent. We will address such questions as: what is the impact of a company’s physical distribution structure on the intra logistics system, and vice versa? What storage systems should be used under which circumstances, what handling systems, what is the best layout, which information systems are appropriate, and what is the resulting performance? Besides matters of system choice, operational storage and order picking strategies are also discussed.
During the course, a number of case-based assignments will be carried out. You may have to present your solutions in class.

The course addresses several skills. These include presentations, consultancy (you have to defend solutions to your peers), data-mining with a database tool, design, and analysis of company-internal operations.

column1: Families are a key link between macro-level processes (political, cultural, and economic shifts) and individual outcomes such as socioeconomic and health status in later life. Many of the decisions that people might perceive as fundamentally personal and individual (the kind of job taken or whether to work at all, whether to become a parent or not, which country to live in) are shaped by the interaction between our families and broader social, cultural, and institutional conditions.

In this course, students will learn about the links between families and social inequalities. We will not only look at social class as dimension of social inequality, but also focus on differences by ethnicity, race, sexuality and gender. Students will gain insights into key theoretical and methodological approaches to the study of families and social inequalities. Attention will be paid to interactions between micro- and macro-levels of analysis; e.g. how markets (e.g. the precariousness of jobs), states (e.g. social policies and national laws) and political, cultural and economic shifts structure family members’ life courses and well-being outcomes, thereby reducing, maintaining or strengthening social inequalities at large.

The course is theory-based and empirical, and thus questions whether claims based on theory are supported by empirical evidence. It also seeks explanations for empirical phenomena. Moreover, tutorials will use empirical evidence in debates.

column1: Dutch culture is marked by two interdependent themes: the color orange and a history of colonization. While the first, orange, is expressed in the (un)popularity of the Royal Family (with the epitome of the King’s Birthday Celebration), soccer, and mythical narrations of how the Netherlands as a small country was a refuge for artists, philosophers, and religious people. The second has much more negative expression that marks contemporary debates. The fierceness of debates on ‘Zwarte Piet’ (black Pete), the images of slaves on the Royal family’s Golden carriage, or museums’ attempts at decolonization are just a few examples of how the Dutch struggle with their past.

In this course, students will familiarize themselves with both themes from the three perspectives our faculty offers. Starting with a historical perspective, students will form a firm understanding of the meanings of ‘orange’ and the colonial history. Both important foundations for current Dutch culture. Building onto this understanding, student will explore how these two themes impacted the current art world. While the Netherlands have brought forth many important (visual) artists, Dutch museums are also struggling with the Dutch colonial past. Last but not least, the last two weeks will be dedicated to exploring popular culture’s expressions of these two themes. The TV format trade and Dutch soccer culture will be taken as a case.</body>

column1: This course introduces students to the field of feminist philosophy through key texts by some of the most prominent figures in the field, such as Simone de Beauvoir, Judith Butler, Audre Lorde, Donna Haraway and Luce Irigaray. Through the analysis of these texts, we will engage with a genealogy of feminist philosophy and explore one of its most contested sites of debate: the body.

We will start by critically assessing mainstream canonical philosophy, which has relied on a hierarchically charged binary opposition between mind and body that also correlates with the opposition between masculinity and femininity.  The course will examine how such binary thinking relates to structural (gender) inequalities, and how this has elevated the theorizing of the body in critical feminist thought. By unpacking different feminist positions regarding the themes of embodiment and binaries, students will develop an understanding of key traditions within the field of feminist philosophy, including sexual difference theory, gender performativity, feminist phenomenology and feminist new materialisms.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Have a basic understanding of key texts within the field of feminist philosophy of the body.
• Have a basic understanding of key re-conceptualisations of the body within feminist philosophy.
• Have a basic understanding of key thinkers in feminist philosophy such as Lloyd, de Beauvoir, Irigaray, Haraway, Butler, Young and hooks.
• Be able to describe and explain the problematic relation between feminism, philosophy and the body.
• Be able to describe and explain how the rational subject has typically been constructed against the natural realm and what this entails.
• Be able to describe and explain what is at stake politically, ethically and epistemologically in rethinking the body in feminist theory.
• Have a basic understanding of feminist stakes in addressing, and sometimes going beyond, binary thinking.

column1: Kwesties uit de methodologie van de economie, zoals de vragen hoe onrealistisch economische modellen mogen en moeten zijn en hoe we kunnen beoordelen hoe groot hun verklarende kracht is, en kwesties uit de ethiek van de economie, zoals de vraag naar het doel van economisch beleid, naar ongelijkheid, verdelende rechtvaardigheid en morele grenzen van de markt, worden in de hoorcolleges geïntroduceerd en toegelicht. In vijf werkgroepen worden ethische kwesties in het bedrijfsleven en in de markt besproken en geanalyseerd. Door actief met de materie bezig te zijn ontwikkelen studenten een sterker moreel besef en maken zij zich denkkaders eigen om tot een meer doordachte en evenwichtige eigen oordeelsvorming te komen.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

• Studenten zijn in staat om argumenten van filosofen te reconstrueren en beoordelen in premise-conclusie vorm. Studenten zijn in staat om zelf (filosofische) premise-conclusie argumenten te construeren in essay-vorm. Studenten moeten vooral in staat zijn om redenen te geven vóór en tegen de verschillende theorieën die genoemd worden in de gedetailleerde leerdoelen.

• Studenten zijn in staat om een uitleg te geven van de complexiteit van verschillende normatieve concepten die worden bestudeerd door filosofen van de economie met relevantie voor de discussies van economie en sociaal beleid. In het bijzonder zijn studenten in staat om de abstracte concepten die worden genoemd in de gedetailleerde leerdoelen te definiëren en onderscheiden, waarbij ook wordt verwacht dat ze zelf voorbeelden bedenken om deze verschillen mee te illustreren.

• Studenten zijn in staat om deze abstracte normatieve concepten te gebruiken bij het construeren van filosofische argumenten in essay-vorm die betrekking hebben tot concrete gevallen (armoede, onderwijs, gezondheidszorg, stemmen, sweatshops), zoals uitgelegd in de gedetailleerde leerdoelen.
• Studenten zijn in staat om samen te werken met andere studenten bij het plannen, opstellen, en herzien van zulk soort essay.

• Studenten zijn in staat om voorbeelden te verzinnen die helpen bij het onderscheiden van de hedonistische, voorkeursbevredigings- (preference satisfaction) en Sen en Nussbaums capabiliteits-opvattingen van welzijn. Studenten worden in staat geacht redenen te leveren vóór en tegen iedere opvatting, in premise-conclusie-vorm. Ze dienen in staat te zijn om de verschillende implicaties van deze theorieën uit te leggen voor het conceptualiseren van armoede, bijvoorbeeld in discussies over absolute versus relatieve definities van armoede.

•  Studenten zijn in staat om onderscheid te maken tussen verschillende opvattingen van eerlijkheid. Studenten zijn in staat om Broome’s theorie van eerlijkheid te formuleren. Studenten zijn in staat om uit te leggen hoe goedheid en eerlijkheid uiteenvallen, met name bij het gebruiken van QALY’s voor het verdelen van medische middelen.

• Studenten zijn in staat om een narratief te vormen over de historische achtergrond van het gelijkheids- versus toereikendheidsdebat in het onderwijs. Studenten kunnen de gelijkheids- versus toereikendheidsdistinctie voor sufficiency in verdelingsrechtvaardigheid uitleggen. Studenten dienen in staat te zijn om te pleiten vóór of tegen een gelijkheids- of toereikendheids-norm voor het verdelen van onderwijsmiddelen en -kansen. Studenten zijn in staat om Debra Satz’ positie in het gelijkheids- versus toereikendheidsdebat in het onderwijs te beoordelen.

• Studenten zijn in staat om de theorieën van exploitatie, namelijk schending van rechten, oneerlijke uitwisseling, eerlijke verdeling, en dominantie, te noemen. Studenten dienen ook te kunnen uitleggen hoe deze van elkaar verschillen. Ze dienen in staat te zijn om redenen vóór en tegen iedere opvatting te geven, en om eigen voorbeelden te leveren om hun argumenten te ondersteunen. Ze dienen in staat te zijn om de implicaties van iedere theorie uit te leggen bij het beoordelen van Powell en Zwolinski’s argument dat sweatshops uitbuitend zijn.

• Studenten dienen in staat te zijn om de basisconcepten en -uitkomsten (Condorcet-paradox, Arrow’s theorem, Gibbard-Satterthwaite theorem) van Socialekeuzetheorie te definiëren. Ook dienen studenten in staat te zijn om verscheidene socialekeuzefuncties toe te passen. Studenten dienen enkele prominenten axiomen van socialekeuzefuncties te kunnen uitleggen en toepassen. Studenten dienen te kunnen uitleggen wat, volgens William Riker, de voornaamste uitkomst is van de basisresultaten van socialekeuzetheorie voor ons begrip van democratie.

column1: De cursus is uitsluitend bedoeld voor de voltijdstudenten. Aanwezigheid en participatie zijn verplicht.
Deze cursus bestaat uit een 'Filosofisch Atelier I'-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 1A en 1B, en een 'Filosofie en Film'-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 2A.

In het eerste jaar van de bachelor krijg je een introductie op academisch onderwijs. De focus ligt hier op studievaardigheden. Al tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst zal worden gezocht naar een goede balans tussen jouw verwachtingen en de eisen die de studie stelt. Ook zal aandacht worden besteed aan motivatie, attitude en het structureren van zelfstudie (voorbereiding op colleges en tentamens). Er zijn bijeenkomsten voorzien over ‘de ethiek van het lezen’, waarin verschillende genres teksten worden besproken en de daarbij passende houding van de lezer. Maar er worden ook bijeenkomsten gewijd aan het volgen van hoorcolleges, het gebruik van de UB, citeren, verwijzen en frauderen, en het schrijven van een samenvatting.

Aanvullend hierop wordt als onderdeel van deze introductie één college gegeven met als thema loopbaanoriëntatie. Het doel van dit college is om je kennis te laten maken met de loopbaanperspectieven en om (voor jezelf) expliciet te formuleren wat je uiteindelijk verwacht van de opleiding.

Ook wordt tijdens dit college verteld over de mogelijkheden om jezelf naast de opleiding te ontwikkelen. Hierbij gaat het om informatie over het Honoursprogramma, exchange, medezeggenschap, commissie of bestuur bij ERA en het lopen van stage.

In het ‘Filosofie en Film’-gedeelte van deze cursus staat een urgent filosofisch probleem centraal waarrond een aantal films wordt geselecteerd en vertoond. Verschillende docenten verzorgen colleges over het thema en de gekozen films. Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij essays schrijven, elkaars essays beoordelen, en presenteren en discussiëren over de films en het thema. De nadere invulling van dit deel van de cursus wordt via Canvas bekend gemaakt.

2. Kan je zelfstandig een filosofische tekst lezen, analyseren en samenvatten.
3. Ken je de regels wat betreft het schrijven van een academisch filosofische tekst.
4. Weet je welke hulpmiddelen en faciliteiten de universiteit biedt ter ondersteuning van je studie.
5. Weet je welke mogelijkheden er zijn om je in en naast je studie persoonlijk te ontwikkelen.
6. Heb je een onderbouwde visie op de loopbaankansen na de studie filosofie.
Het doel van Filosofie en Film is:

a) Inzicht krijgen in de academische beoefening van filosofie en het vermogen ontwikkelen om in korte opdrachten de filosofische thematiek en importantie van verschillende films onder woorden te brengen.
b) Het opdoen van de basisvaardigheden van het schrijven van een filosofisch artikel.

column1: De cursus is uitsluitend bedoeld voor de voltijdstudenten. Aanwezigheid en participatie zijn verplicht.
Deze cursus bestaat uit een scriptiewerkgroep-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 2A en 2B, en een 'Filosofisch Atelier III'-gedeelte dat plaatsvindt in blok 3A, 3B en 4A.

In een aantal bijeenkomsten van november tot en met januari wordt een technische instructie gegeven voor het schrijven van een bachelor thesis en wordt collectief gewerkt aan eenieders concept voor de thesis. Dat concept dient uiterlijk 1 februari, goedgekeurd door de begeleider, aan de Examencommissie te worden voorgelegd. Voltijdstudenten die in 2022-2023 hun bachelorexamen willen afleggen dienen deel te nemen aan de bijeenkomsten. Zonder deelname kan geen bachelorexamen worden afgelegd.

In jaar 3 ga je verder met het portfolio en voer je een individueel gesprek met de loopbaanadviseur. In dit gesprek wordt er met je gesproken over jouw toekomstplannen. Je schrijft een reflectie op dit gesprek.
Tot slot neem je deel aan de Week van het Werk waarin verschillende workshops worden verzorgd, waaronder trainingen op het gebied van sollicitatievaardigheden.

column1: Het doel van de scriptiewerkgroep is:
a) Het schrijven van een concept voor de eigen bachelor thesis.
b) Het presenteren en kritisch bespreken van tekstgedeelten uit de eigen thesis.
c) Het constructief-kritisch becommentariëren van tekstgedeelten uit de theses van medestudenten.
d) Het komen tot een eerste volledige versie van de thesis.
1. Weet je hoe je jouw verdere (studie)loopbaan na de bachelor gaat vormgeven met behulp van een gesprek met de loopbaanadviseur.
2. Ken je de belangrijkste onderdelen die betrekking hebben op solliciteren.

column1: Als filosofie student ben je dagelijks bezig met complexe problemen en de factoren die zulke problematiek veroorzaken. Dit is altijd een spanningsveld van onenigheid over waarden en doelen en van onzekerheid over kennis. Je beschikt over filosofische kennis en vaardigheden waarmee grote maatschappelijk vraagstukken kunnen worden gedefinieerd, geanalyseerd en geherstructureerd. Die eigenschappen komen goed van pas in de maatschappelijke context, waar problemen vrijwel altijd complex van aard zijn.

Om jouw kennis en vaardigheden in te kunnen zetten voor een maatschappelijke impact moet je leren samenwerken met de buitenwereld. Hiervoor zijn het ontwikkelen van professionele en praktische vaardigheden van belang. Tijdens deze stage word je uitgedaagd om je verder als professional te ontwikkelen. Enerzijds zet je jouw filosofische kennis en vaardigheden bij organisaties in en anderzijds ontwikkel je nieuwe, hands-on vaardigheden in een werkveld naar jouw keuze.

De stage vindt plaats tijdens de minorperiode, in blok 1A en 1B van het derde bachelorjaar (10 weken totaal). Gedurende de stage werk je aan je professionele ontwikkeling en aan een impactproject. Zowel voor de professionele ontwikkeling als voor het impactproject bieden we inhoudelijke workshops en sessies aan, zoals intervisie en feedbackmomenten. Tijdens die momenten kom je met medestudenten die ook stage lopen samen en help je elkaar verder.</body>

column1: ​FinTech covers digital innovation and technology-enabled business model innovation in the financial services. FinTech is rapidly evolving across the globe and represents an existential challenge for major parts of the industry. This course provides an introductory overview of innovations that are central to FinTech in the areas of payment, capital raising, investment, and credit. Specifically, the main focus is on blockchain technology and its specific issues and applications. However, other important innovations covered include crowdfunding, robo-advising, social trading, peer-to-peer lending, mobile money, and central bank digital currency. The course also explores threats and opportunities that these technologies pose to incumbent firms and discuss the way that FinTech interacts with law enforcement and regulation issues. Furthermore, the course features a number of guest speakers from industry.

column1: The financial sector has been increasingly disrupted by the use of technology. Moreover, recent regulations such as Mifid I&II and the EU PSD2 directive, have created an environment that further facilitates the use of technology, big data, and algorithms in financing applications. One can think about payment systems, Peer to Peer Lending, Crowdfunding, Crypto-currencies, Robo Advising, and High-Frequency Trading.

The course consists of two parts that run sequentially. In the first part, we discuss the FinTech business models and strategies, their value propositions, their impact on traditional players in the financial sector, and their impact on market outcomes. During the first part, students start to work on a business plan for a FinTech Venture.

In the second part of the course, we apply the knowledge gathered thus far in this course and the core courses by implementing a stylized version of the key technology (minimum viable product or MVP) for the FinTech venture embarked on in the first part under the supervision of an instructor with ample experience in FinTech bootcamps and hackathons.

column1: In dit vak staan drie vraagstukken centraal: het investerings-, het prijsvormings- en het beleggings- vraagstuk.

Het investeringsvraagstuk betreft de vraag hoe bedrijven het beste kunnen bepalen in welke projecten zij zouden moeten investeren indien waarde creatie centraal staat. Wij bespreken verschillende inves- teringsselectiemethoden die in de praktijk worden gebruikt waarbij de netto contante waarde methode centraal staat. Deze methode wordt namelijk beschouwd als het meest geschikte investeringsselectie- criterium indien maximalisatie van waarde wordt nagestreefd.

Het prijsvormingsvraagstuk betreft de verklaring van marktprijzen van vermogenstitels zoals aandelen en obligaties. Wij gaan in op de waardebepaling door de vermogensmarkt van aandelen maar ook op die van obligaties uitgegeven door ondernemingen en overheden. Vragen die gesteld worden zijn: Wat is de invloed van de te verwachte dividendbetalingen en het marktrisico op de prijs van het aandeel? Wat is de invloed van de termijnstructuur van de rentevoeten op de prijs van een obligatie? Hoe beïn- vloeden de couponbetalingen de prijs van een obligatie? Is het mogelijk om waarde te creëren door het dividend te verlagen en meer te investeren in groei? Wie heeft er voordeel bij een overname?

Het beleggingsvraagstuk wordt benaderd aan de hand van de portefeuilletheorie van Markowitz. Je maakt tevens kennis met het zogenaamde Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In de praktijk wordt het CAPM gebruikt bij het bepalen van disconteringsvoeten die nodig zijn bij toepassing van investe- ringsselectiemethoden.

• Het uitleggen van het CAPM en het toepassen van het model ten einde een vermogenskos- tenvoet vast te stellen;
• Het uitleggen van de Efficiënte Markt Hypothese en het analyseren van de implicaties ervan.

column1: The performance of a corporation depends on how well managers succeed in creating value. This course will demonstrate how several financial theories can be applied in order to create value. In this course, we discuss three main issues in finance: capital budgeting, asset pricing and financial invest- ments.

The capital budgeting decision involves how firms select projects that create value. We emphasize the net present value method, which is considered as the most frequently used optimal decision method. In addition, we also discuss several other selection criteria and explain how these criteria are related to the net present value method.

The asset pricing part concerns the way financial assets are priced by the market. The focus is on the pricing of stocks issued by firms and bonds issued by firms and governments. Questions raised are: What is the influence of the expected stream of dividends and the level of market risk of firm’s projects on the price of stocks? How are the term structure of interest rates and promised coupon payments related to bond prices? Is it possible to create value by lowering the pay-out ratio and investing in growth? Who benefits from the value that is added when a takeover occurs?

The financial investment decision is approached from a portfolio perspective and ends with a discussion of the Capital Asset Pricing Model (CAPM). In practice, this model is often used to set a discount rate for capital budgeting purposes.

• Explain Portfolio Theory and apply this theory to form portfolios of financial assets;
• Explain the CAPM and apply this model to determine the cost of capital;
• Explain the Efficient Markets Hypothesis and analyse its implications.

column1: Dit vak behandelt de kennis die nodig is om een onderneming te kunnen waarderen. De waarde van de onderneming beinvloedt de beurskoers van een aandeel van die onderneming en bepaalt de prijs die betaalt wordt voor de aandelen van de onderneming bij een fusie of overname. Vanuit de perspectieven van een financieel manager en de financiers van de onderneming behandelt Finance 1: valuation hoe investerings- en financieringsbeslissingen de waarde van de onderneming beïnvloeden. We gaan niet alleen uit van de klassieke rationele winst-maximalisatie denkwijze, maar besteden ook aandacht aan recente ontwikkelingen op het gebied van behavioural finance en het financieren van duurzaamheid.

Finance 1: valuation omvat hoorcolleges, tutorial sessions, webcasts en on-line oefeningen. Tijdens de wekelijks colleges behandelen verschillende docenten de stof. Tijdens de tutor sessions worden actuele case studies besproken, waardoor studenten zien hoe de stof wordt toegepast bij echte investeringsbeslissingen, beursintroducties en overnames. In webcasts worden oefeningen besproken en geven docenten extra toelichting.

column1: During this course we'll study the knowledge necessary to value a firm. The value of the firm influences the prices of its shares en determines the price paid for shares in case of mergers and acquisitions. From the perspective of the financial manager and the financers of the firm Finance 1: valuation will show how investment and financing decisions influence the value of the firm. Besides thinking in terms of classical rational profit maximization thinking, we'll address important developments in behavioural finance and sustainability as well.

Finance 1: valuation encompasses classes, tutorial sessions, webcasts and on-line exercises. During the weekly classes, teacher present knowledge. The tutorial sessions will be focused around real-life case studies, such that students understand how the knowledge is applied for real investment decisions, IPO's and take overs. The webcasts are short films wherein exercises will be discuss and teacher give additional information.

column1: In the last phase of your study, it is important to apply the knowledge and skills you have developed by doing an internship. There is an option to do an internship as part of your MSc in Finance & Investments by choosing the Internship Elective in Block 5. column1: Achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is the grand challenge of our time. This course gives insight in ‘how the financial system can contribute to sustainable development’.

The finance transition is about transforming the financial system from operating on financial value only to working with the concept of integrated value, which combines financial, social and ecological value. The concept of integrated value is approached from an academic and practical angle (e.g. incorporating social and ecological value flows alongside the financial cash flows in the net present value (NPV) calculation).
Students apply the integrated value concept in exercises and a group assignment.
