column1: Het vak Geschiedenis van het Privaatrecht behandelt de beperking van aansprakelijkheid in verschillende historische perioden, met het accent op handels- en ondernemingsrecht.

Allereerst komt het Romeinse recht aan de orde. Handelsactiviteiten werden in de hogere Romeinse kringen eigenlijk als ‘not done’ beschouwd, maar de mogelijkheid om er inkomsten mee te verwerven bleek in de praktijk toch te aantrekkelijk. Veelal liet een Romeinse pater familias de uitvoering over aan slaven of ondergeschikten. Aan de hand van (vertaalde) teksten uit het Corpus Iuris Civilis zal worden nagegaan hoe zijn aansprakelijkheid in dat kader gestalte kreeg. Voor delicten van slaven was hij ten volle aansprakelijk, zij het dat hij kon volstaan met het uitleveren van de slaaf aan de gelaedeerde; voor door slaven gesloten contracten was hij slechts aansprakelijk voor zover hij hun een peculium (werk­vermogen) had toegekend of tot de hoogte van zijn uit het contract voortgevloeide verrijking. Ook kon hij optreden als financier achter een (meestal, maar niet per definitie) vrije institor (filiaalhouder), of als exercitor (reder) van een schip, bestuurd door een magister navis (schipper). Aandacht wordt ook besteed aan de societas (maatschap / vennootschap)  en de lex Rhodia de iactu (de Rhodische wet inzake zeeworp). Een interessante vraag daarbij is in hoeverre deze rechtsfiguren in het latere recht gerecipieerd zijn.

Na de instorting van het Westelijk deel van het Romeinse rijk krijgt de handel in Europa vanaf circa 1100 nieuwe impulsen dankzij technische vooruitgang in de scheepvaart. Handelssteden en -netwerken komen op die hun macht en welvaart vooral danken aan hun overzeese handelsverbindingen met andere steden. Daarvoor zijn schepen nodig en ook toen al was veel kapitaal nodig om schepen te laten bouwen. Daarbij deed zich echter het probleem voor dat scheepvaart weliswaar zeer lucratief kan zijn maar tevens grote gevaren en financiële risico’s met zich meebrengt. In een tijd dat er nog geen andere alternatieven bestonden om de risico’s verbonden aan scheepvaart in te dammen ontwikkelde zich geleidelijk de gedachte aan een scheiding tussen het zeevermogen (fortune de mer) en het landvermogen (fortune de terre) van een scheepseigenaar. Via rechtsfiguren als de rederij, de commanditaire vennootschap, het abandon van schip en vracht, het executie- en het fondsenstelsel kreeg het leerstuk van de beperking van aansprakelijkheid van de scheepseigenaar gestalte. Hoewel omstreden heeft deze bijzonderheid van het zee- en binnenvaart­recht zich tot de dag van vandaag weten te handhaven.

De kapitaalvennootschap wordt wel beschouwd als een van de instituties die een cruciale bijdrage hebben geleverd aan de westerse economische ontwikke­ling in de afgelopen eeuwen. De BV heet niet voor niets voluit besloten vennootschap met beperkte aansprakelijkheid. De beperkte aansprakelijkheid maakte het mogelijk om kapitaal aan te trekken waarmee ondernemerschap werd bevorderd. Aan de hand van het thema beperkte aansprakelijkheid van aandeelhouders en bestuurders onderzoeken we de geschiedenis van de kapitaalvennootschap die begon bij de oprichting van de VOC in 1602. Welke gevaren zag de wetgever van het Wetboek van Koophandel van 1838 in deze rechtsvorm? Hoe is het leerstuk van bestuurders­aansprakelijkheid ontstaan? Wat is de ratio van de beperkte aansprakelijkheid en wat zijn haar gevaren? Deze vragen worden behandeld in historisch perspectief en in hun actualiteit.

Als (ortho)pedagoog en onderwijskundige voer je professionele gesprekken met zowel volwassenen als kinderen. Het practicum ‘gespreksvaardigheden II’ is gericht op gesprekken met kinderen. Er zijn verschillende vormen van gesprekken die je met kinderen kunt voeren, zoals een open vraaggesprek of een hulpverleningsgesprek. In dit practicum richten we ons op het voeren van een interview: een interview met een kind. Het interview dat je bij het kind gaat afnemen (het semigestructureerd klinische interview voor kinderen en adolescenten, SCICA) is uitsluitend gericht op het verkrijgen van informatie van het kind met als doel om het kind beter te leren kennen. Het practicum ‘Gespreksvaardigheden II’ bouwt voort op twee practica die je al hebt afgerond, namelijk het practicum ‘Gespreksvaardigheden I’ en het practicum ‘Neuropsychological testing of children’.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: In daily and business life, you can find yourself in situations where you want to get something done, but you do not have much to offer as an exchange. For example, you want to initiate a project or business, but you are lacking cash, knowledge and resources. You may have an idea for a great new product, but your superiors are only supportive when it takes a limited investment and no excessive risks. Or you want to expand your network with some highly-regarded people, potential employers or difficult to approach customers for your own business, but those people may not find you very interesting. These situations are in a basic sense similar to all ‘ventures’ where success depends on your ability to mobilize other people and to reduce risks. Entrepreneurial bootstrapping is the pursuit of success (or getting things done) with limited resources and free outside help. In general, bootstrapping refers to a self-starting and self-sustaining process that is supposed to proceed without external help or input. In the entrepreneurship literature four subthemes of bootstrapping can be distinguished, namely: informal and creative resource acquisition, the use of networks and persuasive skills, entrepreneurial marketing and entrepreneurial finance. In class, these basic principles of bootstrapping will be discussed extensively.

First, in the so-called creative resource acquisition perspective, bootstrapping is an original strategy of obtaining resources without a big spending effort), for instance through a direct exchange of goods and/or services with others without money (barter trade) or by making creative use of the limited resources one has at its disposal (e,g. effectuation, frugal innovation and bricolage).

Second, networking is at the heart of any bootstrapping effort. The lectures will cover networking theory, i.e. the purposes and potential effects of networking, and how networking partners and cold calls can be a source of free information and advice, followed by paying attention to more specific networking skills on how to get in touch and build a relationship, and subsequently, how to influence other people and/or benefit from ‘relevant others’, such as friends, family members, mentors and coaches.

Third, in discussing the topic of entrepreneurial marketing, an exploration is sought of the emerging phenomena of innovation by users, open-source projects, and crowdsourcing. User innovation basically implies that there are many users out there who develop their own products to use themselves – and they generally share their innovations for free! Open-source projects imply that a distributed community of users contributes to an overall project. Crowdsourcing, finally, is the act of outsourcing tasks to an undefined, large group of people or community through an open call, implying that you can mobilize people to work for you.

Fourth, within the framework of entrepreneurial finance, bootstrapping refers to the different financial strategies entrepreneurs pursue to keep the venture under their control (not diluting all kinds of bootstrapping techniques involving cheap ownership and equity in the company), turning key fixed costs into variable costs, or by effectively managing cash flows and making process within the firm efficient. The entrepreneurial finance approach will be elaborated by considering money and crowdfunding.

column1: The aim of this course is to study and expand the theory of bootstrapping, and to apply bootstrapping techniques in practice. column1: De ontwikkeling van het kind vormt de basis van het werk van pedagogen, waarbij de vraag “hoe zorg ik ervoor dat een kind zich zo optimaal mogelijk kan ontwikkelen?” centraal staat. Welk type opvoeding is het beste voor een kind? Hoe werkt opvoeden bij ouders met een verstandelijke beperking? Wat is de invloed van leeftijdgenoten op de ontwikkeling en het gedrag van kinderen? De gezinspedagogiek bestudeert de ontwikkeling en opvoeding van kinderen en daarbij behorende opvoedvragen van ouders. Pedagogische vraagstukken over onder andere het nature-nurture-debat, adoptie, kinderopvang, kindermishandeling en opvoedstijlen worden behandeld in deze minor. De theoretische basis voor het bestuderen van de context waarin het kind opgroeit wordt gevormd door het sociaalecologische model van Bronfenbrenner waarbij het kind zich ontwikkelt in interactie met zijn omgeving: bijvoorbeeld ouders, school en kinderopvang en leeftijdgenoten.

Naast de opvoeding in verschillende contexten, worden gezinnen in verschillende contexten bestudeerd. Het gezin anno 2022 kent veel meer verschijningsvormen dan het traditionele kerngezin (vader, moeder en hun kinderen). In deze minor zullen we de verschillende wijzen waarop een gezin gevormd kan worden bestuderen. Hierbij kunnen we enerzijds gezinnen onderscheiden waarbij de manier waarop het gezin gevormd wordt niet-traditioneel is (bijv. adoptie, pleegzorg of IVF) en anderzijds gezinnen waarbij de betrokken ouders zelf niet aan het traditionele beeld voldoen (bijv. homo-ouders of tienermoeders). Het gaat hierbij dus om niet-traditionele gezinsvormen. Daarnaast kan ook de samenstelling van het gezin soms niet-traditioneel genoemd worden. Tegenwoordig wordt het traditionele kerngezin vaak voorgesteld als een vader, een moeder en twee kinderen. Gezinnen met meer dan drie of vier kinderen zijn bijzonder, maar ook een gezin met één kind zou niet-traditioneel genoemd kunnen worden. Tot slot kunnen er zich in de loop der jaren ook ontwikkelingen voordoen in gezinnen (bijv. echtscheiding of overlijden van een ouder) waardoor niet-traditionele gezinnen ontstaan (bijv. eenoudergezinnen of samengestelde gezinnen). Het niet-traditionele gezin kent dus vele gezichten. Hoe vaak komen deze verschillende gezinsvormen en gezinssamenstellingen eigenlijk voor? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor de ontwikkeling van het kind in deze gezinnen? Welke gevolgen heeft dit voor het ouderschap en het welzijn van de ouder? Is er ondersteuning nodig bij deze gezinnen en is die ondersteuning effectief? In deze minor wordt een antwoord op deze vragen geformuleerd.

column1: <body>Recht ordent. Dat gebeurt door regels, beginselen en rechterlijke uitspraken. Gezondheidsrecht is een gebied binnen het algemene recht met eigen karaktertrekken. Sterker dan in andere gebieden spelen grondrechten een rol, zoals privacy en lichamelijke integriteit. Daarnaast kenmerkt het gezondheidsrecht door de aandacht voor de patiënt. Om het gezondheidsrecht te begrijpen is basiskennis van het algemene recht noodzakelijk, zoals de diverse algemene rechtsgebieden. Denk aan bestuursrecht, privaatrecht grondrechten en internationaal recht. Het gezondheidsrecht kent zijn eigen wetgeving inzake rechten van de patiënt, financiering van de zorg, kwaliteit van zorg en de verantwoordelijkheid voor bepaalde zorg en maatschappelijke ondersteuning. Daar wordt in dit vak op ingegaan.</body>

Het gezondheidsrecht is het functioneel rechtsgebied dat zich met de inrichting en het goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg bezighoudt. Het is als zodanig van grote maatschappelijke waarde. Voor dat goed functioneren van de gezondheidszorg wordt in toenemende mate en via een steeds groter wordende diversiteit van thema’s ook een beroep gedaan op het strafrecht. Veel wetten op het gebied van de gezondheidszorg (inzake medicijnengebruik, orgaandonatie, etc.) bevatten strafbepalingen. Voorts kan het begaan van strafbare feiten door werkers in de gezondheidszorg (BIG-geregistreerden) het vertrouwen in de gezondheidszorg aantasten. Niet voor niets bevatten de artikelen 96 en 96a Wet BIG eigen strafbare feiten ter voorkoming van de benadeling van de gezondheidszorg alsmede een eigen regeling om een werker in de gezondheidszorg uit het beroep te ontzetten. Belangrijker is de toenemende roep naar strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid (of ten minste onderzoek daarna) in geval er bij medische missers sprake is van een calamiteit in de zin van de WKKGz, hetgeen al snel ook het vermoeden van een strafbaar feit zal impliceren. Dan komt bij onderzoek al snel de vraag op naar de strafrechtelijke positie van de betrokkene/arts, al dan niet in verhouding tot de instelling (ziekenhuis als verdachte) en dan is ook het medisch beroepsgeheim en verschoningsrecht in het geding. In de strafvordering is het recht van de patiënt op onderzoek erkend als een dringende reden op basis waarvan het verschoningsrecht in het opsporingsonderzoek moet wijken. Dat verschoningsrecht staat sowieso onder druk. Zo onder andere in het bredere beleidsdossier tot het vergroten van de mogelijkheden om ‘ fraude in de zorg’ te bestrijden. Tegelijkertijd heeft het strafrecht ook zijn eigen uitgangspunten en structuur die de ‘functionaliteit’ van het rechtsgebied ook wel weer beperken.

Twee terreinen kunnen nog in het bijzonder nader worden genoemd. Dat is in de eerste plaats de bescherming van de openbare orde en veiligheid tegen (verwarde) personen die al of niet een strafbaar feit hebben begaan. Door de WvGGZ en de Wfz zijn per 1 januari 2020 hoge verwachtingen gewekt met en hoge eisen gesteld aan een betere afstemming van zorg en dwang ter zake. Het andere bijzondere thema betreft het strafrecht en indringende vragen betreffende het begin en het einde van het leven. Zoals bekend, bestaat in Nederland een regeling waarbinnen uitsluitend de arts onder strikte voorwaarde euthanasie of hulp bij zelfdoding mag verrichten, inclusief euthanasie bij ernstig gehandicapte pasgeborenen. De hele regeling wordt via het strafrecht gecontroleerd. Alle maatschappelijke controverses verdienen ruim aandacht in dit vak.

De uitbreiding van de betekenis van het strafrecht wordt geïllustreerd door het feit dat binnen het OM een Expertisecentrum Medische Zaken (EMZ) is ingericht. Dat zal zich in voorkomende gevallen van strafrechtelijke rechtshandhaving ook over de verhouding met het medisch tuchtrecht moeten buigen.
Aan het einde van het vak kan de student zelfstandig:

column2: • De raakvlakken tussen het strafrecht en het gezondheidsrecht formuleren en waarderen
• De typische strafbepalingen van de gezondheidszorg, zoals art. 96 Wet op de beroepen in de individuele gezondheidszorg (BIG) analyseren en becommentariëren
• Het strafrecht als controlesysteem binnen de reguliere en alternatieve gezondheidszorg mede in verhouding tot de wet kwaliteit, klachten en geschillen zorg (Wkkgz) becommentariëren
• De wezenlijke samenhang van het strafrecht bij medisch handelen bij begin en einde van het leven formuleren en waarderen
• De bijzondere positie van de arts als verschoningsgerechtigde, de gezondheidszorg in detentie en het ziekenhuis als rechtspersoon formuleren en waarderen
• Een beargumenteerd standpunt formuleren met betrekking tot een stelling of casus over de rol van het strafrecht in de gezondheidszorg

The course Global and European Governance provides an introduction governance beyond nation-states. The first part of the course introduces students into the study of international politics, with special attention to the role of international institutions and regionalism. The tutorials will focus on applying the lessons from the lectures to the particular policy questions at hand.

In the second part, students will concentrate on the European Union. The European Union is the most advanced instance of international cooperation in the history of humankind. The course will focus on the main institutional aspects of the European Union, economic integration as well on political integration, and the role of the EU in the world. We will also discuss the rise of Euroscepticism. The tutorials focus on analyzing EU policies, discuss Euroscepticism, and model EU bargaining.

column1: Technological advances and global market expansion require marketers, advertisers and communicators to develop an understanding of the developments and factors influencing their field. An increasing number of Western companies are looking to compete in non-western markets as the saturated markets in their own country offer only limited opportunity for growth. In this course, students will explore how a variety of companies target customers in different cultures and how they attempt to make educated decisions with respect to research, strategy, media, implementation and evaluation in today's globalized marketplace. Students will analyze and reflect upon different approaches that companies are using to communicate with diverse audiences across the globe.

Drawing on various communication models, students will analyze and interpret current advertising messages and issues arising from the creation and distribution of such messages in other countries in  a variety of different media.</body>

column1: The ultimate challenges of global advertising are about preserving a balance between the culture of the brand and the culture of the consumers. In practice, many companies use standardized advertising strategies and tactics across the globe (i.e., use identical headlines and/or visuals in different countries). Although the practice of standardization reduces the costs of global advertising, it may also limit its appeal and effectiveness. Standardization, therefore, is highly debated in theory.

In the research workshop Global Advertising, students will first be familiarized with theoretical and empirical literature on the acceptance and use of standardized and localized advertising strategies around the world. Next, students join forces and design and conduct an online survey or experiment to gain an active understanding on the role of consumers’ perceived cultural similarity in global advertising effectiveness.

The research workshop Global Advertising enables students to gain hand-on experience in conducting and describing quantitative research. Two meetings are SPSS-sessions, actively guiding students through the data analysis and interpretation phase. Various sub assignments build up to the final product, which is a complete scientific report. Students get detailed feedback on the sub assignments, allowing them to improve their work.
Note: Working experience with SPSS is desirable, but not compulsory.

column1: This Master course primarily focusses on the global strategic and corporate perspective of multinational enterprises (MNEs). Internalizing international markets and managing operations across borders can be a very profitable exercise for firms. It, however, also comes with considerable risks and challenges. During the course, we will examine the logic behind the strategies MNEs develop to manage the risk and challenges associated with international operations.

Beyond discussing how MNEs aim to be profitable across markets, we will consider the broader societal implications of MNE operations in both their home and host countries. MNEs are generally concerned with containing negative reputation effects that stem from their operations, and with developing a positive image resulting from the way they handle the manifold of societal issues in their firm and environment. We will analyze and formulate strategies through which MNEs can contribute to resolving the pressing societal issues defined in the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) such as inequality, corruption, and climate change.</body>

column1: Global Challenges introduces you to several major societal challenges; many of which you will explore in more depth during subsequent courses throughout your degree. This course will give you an opportunity to explore how various facets of globalization impact the world we live in today.

The course is broadly divided in two parts. First, we sketch a broad story of how globalization has developed in the past few decades. During these weeks, we will talk about globalization and the nation state; whether globalization has changed the way countries deal with transnational conflicts; how institutions can help countries to coordinate their actions; and how the institutional system that has developed in the past few decades is increasingly under pressure by rising powers.

The next three weeks then explore globalization and global challenges from different angles or perspectives. We will look at globalization dynamics from the perspective of gender (exploring the complex relationships between gender and globalization), democracy (asking whether globalization and democracy go hand in hand) and environmentalism (focusing on environmental movements and activism).

Apart from exposing you to different ways of thinking about these challenges, the main goal of Global Challenges is to encourage you to engage in debate with each other. You will learn how to formulate your own argumentation, underpinned by real-world examples. No prior knowledge is assumed.

column1: This course will introduce students to worldwide challenges in health and unhealthy behaviours, with a focus on low- and middle-income countries (LMICs). This will be combined with coaching to further improve students’ presentation skills. We will set the scene by introducing students to the global burden of disease across LMICs. We will identify the relative importance of communicable and non-communicable diseases and the “double burden of disease” these countries are increasingly facing. Then we will explore the limited demand for health care in these countries and interventions to increase this demand including conditional cash transfers. This is followed by interventions to strengthen the supply side of health care systems including performance based financing. We will assess the progress of different countries towards the goal of “Universal Health Coverage”. Throughout the course, students will learn to interpret results of quantitative studies that relate to these different global health topics, identify the use of different types of interventions in global health, and will improve their presentation skills working with a presentation expert.
This course is available for a maximum of 30 students.

column1: International development is a heavily contested field. Some argue that corruption in the developing world is the main reason for countries staying poor, while others point to continuing colonial relationships in the form of, for example, exploitation of the environment and labour in poor countries, Similarly, there is debate on what the most effective development strategies are and on what external actors can do to alleviate poverty. This course aims to provide students with the knowledge and tools to meaningfully participate in these debates. Students get insights in the history of development as well as a thorough knowledge of the theories and debates on causes of economic growth, development and structural transformation, and on the role of human development, institutions, and culture in development. Next to these classical themes, there will be attention for the management of the global challenge of poverty and inequality. This means that issues like sustainable development, the Sustainable Development Goals, the role of foreign aid and of national policies will also be dealt with. The course has a strong empirical emphasis, providing insights in different indicators for development, poverty and inequality and showing available databases and their limitations.

column1: <body>Global environmental dangers are seen by many as the greatest threat to the survival of humanity. How has this link between the environment and human society been constructed over time? What are the proposed solutions to this problem, and how have they been framed, debated, and contested? Giving historical perspective to the environmental issues we face today, this course will cover topics such as energy politics, global environmental governance, and advocacy politics. Focusing on contemporary history, we will discuss questions such as: What were the political implications of moving from coal to oil as energy sources and what consequences might a move to renewable energies entail? How has the relationship between the human and non-human world evolved and should non-humans have political representation? What role did advocacy politics play in the development of our current environmental governance structures and can green consumerism be an effective solution to climate change on a global scale? In doing so, the course will provide you with an understanding of the following three core themes: 1) how ideational and material factors have interacted to shape our understanding of the environment; 2) how individual actions and social structures inform environmental policy at the local and global levels, 3) how historical legacies of colonialism, race, gender, and economic inequality intersect to inform our current perspectives on global environmental politics.</body>

column1: The assertion that global politics is undergoing dramatic change has become a truism. The objective of this course is to understand and contextualise that change. We will critically analyse whether institutions and practices developed during an era in which states were the dominant actors in world politics are able to cope with today’s myriad challenges. How does global politics work in an increasingly interdependent world? Are the institutions of diplomacy and multilateralism equipped to cope with 21st century challenges that are set to change the world profoundly?

The course engages with what has been described as the 'post-Western moment' in global politics. The Western-dominated global political order is increasingly being challenged by 'ising' actors, as well as new issues that are making their presence felt on the global stage: corporations, cities, individuals and other non-state entities.

Key questions that structure this course are centred on global governance: the structure problems that require a global political approach and the practices and structures that address them, the reality of which is rapidly and profoundly changing. Topics range from new forms and innovations in diplomacy as it relates to issues such as multilateralism, geo-economics, culture, security, and climate change</body>

column1: This course deals with the emergence of Global Governance -and its discontents- in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. We will provide topics and themes that highlight human responses, reactions, and rejoinders towards the political processes of (global) institutionalizing and legalizing frameworks. We study transnational migrations; formal and informal intellectual and activist’s networks; and themes from popular culture like, sport, music and food that transcend national and international borders and shape identities beyond the ‘national’. The following twin notions will be dealt with: culture-identity, difference-equality, majority-minority, native-migrant, insiders-outsiders, hyperdiversity-uniformity; bottom-up-top down.

column1: In the developing world, millions of people have no, or limited access to urgently needed health care. Universal access to essential health care is an important but elusive goal. Many poor households are exposed to great financial risks related to ill health, or are forced to forego essential treatments altogether. The World Health Organization has once again put universal health coverage (UHC) high on the policy agenda and the United Nations have embraced the UHC as one of the targets of the Sustainable Development Goals.

Generally, to make progress on the path towards UHC, policy makers in low and middle income countries (LMICs) are required to raise more money for health, to move away from direct payments at the point of use and to use resources for health more efficiently and equitably. This course aims to provide students with a better understanding of each of these three topics and furthermore to evaluate specific health care reforms on this path towards UHC.

The lectures mostly consist of case studies, presenting evidence on health coverage extensions across the developing world. While the course is not focused on teaching new quantitative methods, the sessions do emphasize how the effectiveness of UHC reforms can be evaluated quantitatively.</body>

Global history is the story of interaction. Mankind has engaged in migration and trade since time immemorial. Over the centuries, the different continents, religions and nations have interacted with one another through the exchange of money, goods, information and world views. On the one hand, these contacts may lead to the fusion and mutual influencing of cultures; on the other, they also lead to clashes. Indeed, war, colonisation and decolonisation mark the boundaries of interaction and exchange. In these situations, people have a heightened awareness of what makes their own group ‘unique’. This is yet another age-old phenomenon.

In this series of lectures and tutorials students learn how to structure and periodize Global History into a number of major periods. Discussing these periods, the students become familiar with concepts such as mercantilism, European expansion, colonisation, decolonisation, the postcolonial world and globalisation. Throughout the course, we reflect on the major themes and key developments of human history. Using a variety of case studies and primary sources, the course establishes connections between global developments and their outcomes at the local level.

<body>Students are introduced to the history of the world from 1500 to the present. At the end of the course the students are able to reflect on periodization in global history. They use concepts such as Eurocentrism, colonization, capitalism, resistance, decolonization, post-colonial world and globalisation. Students learn searching and finding primary and secondary sources in the library and use them in a meaningful way in independently written essays.</body>

column1: The contact between individuals and organizations from different countries, cultures, and social groups has never been greater than in our time. In recent decades organizations have continuously globalized their operations, resulting in increasing frequency with which employees interact with colleagues and customers from different cultural backgrounds and ethnicities. At the same time, as a result of legal, social and economic shifts, workforce participation rates of women, minorities, and disabled people have dramatically grown, thus turning diversity into a strategic issue in organizations. Further, as executives operate around broader regions, global teams are formed to address the need to become globally competitive, and customers and suppliers operate across borders, the demands on global executives are ever growing.

This course is designed to help participants develop a deeper understanding of the issues that confront global managers today, and to prepare them for leadership roles in international organizations. Through business cases, experiential exercises, and real-life examples, the course strives to explore knowledge in leading diverse people as well as in leading global organizations. Emphasis will be placed on gaining awareness for the role of culture in organizations and on developing skills to manage diversity.

Each session is a module addressing a particular leadership challenge facing executives in the global arena (e.g., leading a diverse team, managing change, etc.). The teaching approach will vary, with a mix of lecture input, group discussion, case analysis, experiential exercises, and guest lectures.
The students will have the opportunity to learn from the experiences and insights from guest lecturers.
The course grade will be computed as a weighted average of five elements

column1: Through drawing on both Global History and International Relations Theory this course explores the concept and history of global order from 1815 through to the present. Building on the themes and concepts established in The Origins of Global Order, this course centers on two of the 20th century major shifts: the transition from a world of formal empires to a world of formally independent sovereign states, and the transition towards a world dominated by - an increasingly contested - US American hegemony. We will explore how these specific constellations of order emerge and how their dominance is questioned, contested, and undermined. How do they develop and change over time, who are the actors and forces contributing to the rise and fall of specific order constellations? What are the different ideational, material and organizational elements of order holding them together?

column1: International, transnational and domestic actors shape and contest the global regulations and practices we live by. For example, the World Health Organization (WHO), which remains the primary organization involved in global health, provided guidance during the outbreak of Coronavirus. Moreover, the interaction between the WHO, development aid donors and pharmaceutical companies affects access of millions of people to affordable medicine by regulating production and sales of so-called ‘generic drugs’. Such interactions of states, international organisations, NGOs, private actors, legal norms and informal rules create international regimes – sets of written and unwritten rules that guide (but do not predetermine) behaviour in particular policy sectors. These regimes are not just legal rules but practical “ways to do things” on the global arena. Ultimately, international regulatory regimes are an attempt to bring order to anarchy, make sense out of complexity and establish rules and predictability in at least some global policy areas. However, the practice of implementing these global rules is often confusing and contradictory. For instance, anti-money-laundering legislation initiated by the G7 has found higher compliance rates in ‘developing countries’ than in OECD countries. In cases of high-level corruption, it is often NGOs and activist groups which elicit compliance, not the governments who signed anti-corruption legislation. These observations make one ask how we can achieve accountable and effective governance on global and local scales. Do the current rules governing global trade and related activities, including international cooperation in the health sector, provide for a common level playing field?

This course analyses the interaction -both formal and informal - between the different stakeholders (governments, business corporations, civil society representatives etc.) in the development and functioning of international regulations regimes that govern trade and health cooperation, affecting power relations across the globe. Amongst a variety of issues, students will address issues related to the production of generic medicine (TRIPS), fighting money-laundering and tax-evasion as well as bringing transparency to arms trade. By adopting this layout the course reflects on the systemic rules that govern global trade (food, medicine and health, military equipment) and shape our lives, connecting these rules with broader issues like inequality, human rights and political coercion.

Doing so, we challenge the simplistic assumption that global regulatory regimes always transfer most effective and best applicable practices that serve the 'common good'. By going beyond legal aspects, international economics and a focus on international organisations or state actors, this course provides an expansion to the POLIR and EUC curriculum. Students will explore practical issues of global politics in commerce and health to understand how implementation and compliance challenges power asymmetries and international arrangements on a daily basis.

column1: I designed this course to address the core lessons in strategic management with a focus on the global and cross-border issues that managers face in the workplace. The purpose of the course is to introduce international managers to issues that are general, but widely applicable. No background in strategic management is necessary, just a critical mind and a willingness to engage in open discussion on the modern issues multinational enterprises face regularly.

We will focus on three core theories of international strategy: Industry-, Resource-, and Institution-based views. Individually, these theories provided the building blocks for international strategy. Porter (1980) introduced what we now call the industry-based view to help managers better understand competitive dynamics in industries. In the mid 80’s and early 90’s, the revival of resource-based approaches elaborating Penrose (1952) helped to explain how firms may develop capabilities and combine and leverage resources to gain sustained competitive advantages (Barney, 1991; Dierickx & Cool, 1989). And more recently, a group of scholars has been promoting the inclusion of an institution-based view (Peng et al., 2008, 2009) to help explain the rules of game that may shape business and firm outcomes. Together, these theories create the basis for a strategy tripod.

The strategy tripod helps managers to better understand four key questions (Peng et al., 2009): Why do firms differ? How do firms behave? What determines the scope of the firm? What determines the success and failure of firms around the globe? Each of these questions relates to firm performance, the fundamental focus of strategy practitioners and researchers and the core of our course.</body>

3. Distinguish between the three, leading international strategy perspectives and be able to identify the strengths and weakness of each;
4. (In groups) Analyze and develop/create an international strategy case to show their understanding of core international strategy concepts.</body>

column1: Teamwork has long been a vital skill in the workplace. Today’s teams however are more dynamic and “virtual” than ever and are required to operate across disciplinary, temporal, cultural, linguistic, and geographical boundaries. Organizations increasingly rely on such global virtual teams (GVT’s) to participate in the global marketplace, to leverage talent globally, or to tackle global strategic challenges.

Unfortunately, getting global virtual teams to realize this potential is anything but trivial. Communication breakdowns, animosity and conflict across geographical sites, motivational issues, and missed targets are common. Have you mastered the skill of global virtual teamwork? Do you know how to help your team get the best out of its cross-boundary work?

This course aims to sensitize students to the opportunities and challenges of contemporary teamwork, with a focus on global and virtual teamwork. The course consists of a series of interactive lectures, including case studies, exercises, and group discussions, which will equip you with the theoretical knowledge and practical tools to gain insight into your real-life team challenges and deal with such challenges more effectively in the future. As part of the course, you will carry out two team assignments, which include both content and process challenges within your team, which will (ideally) be comprised of members from different national backgrounds (and/or other diversity attributes), collaborating on their tasks remotely. Topics focus on the role of geographical distance, language differences, cultural diversity, and virtuality in teamwork effectiveness.

column1: Supply chain management (SCM) has emerged as one of the major areas for companies to gain a competitive edge. Managing supply chains is a complex and challenging task, due to current business trends of expanding product variety, short product life cycles, increasing outsourcing, globalization of business, and continuous advances in information technology. Supply chain management, as a natural successor to operations management, is a fundamental driver not only for further improving operations but also for strengthening the competitive position of firms. When a company faces the pressure of excessive inventories, degraded customer service, escalating costs and declining profits, or a poor return on assets, its supply chain is out of control. On the other hand, when a company moves into new markets or new technologies, it must have its supply chain prepared for new business challenges and opportunities. The course will introduce students to concepts and techniques related to the design, management and improvement of supply chains and supply chain operations.

The course focuses on a variety of challenging supply chain business situations.  For example, how different types of supply contracts can be used to design win-win solutions between buyer and supplier, how the benefits of information sharing can be estimated in the context of supply chain, and what supply chain strategies match with proliferating product variety. Other topics include, but are not limited to, inventory management, supply chain transportation and distribution network design, operational hedging and global supply chain risk management.

column1: By the end of this course, you will:

column2: • be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the operations and supply chain strategy of companies;
• be able to evaluate opportunities and challenges related to the management of supply chains in (inter)national contexts;
• be able to analyze performance-related business problems and design and propose solutions;
• be able to find relevant literature and apply this to a business case;
• be able to create feasible plans of action and develop sensible decisions on how to deal with a particular supply chain challenge;
• have knowledge of, and skills for, collaborating, managing and coordinating operations in diverse teams and in complex demand-supply networks;
• be able to defend problem formulations and solutions based on sound arguments; and
• be able to critically think about problem definitions and to reflect on solutions proposed by yourself and others.

<body>After an introduction on trade before the industrial revolution, the relation between increased specialisation, industrialisation and the growth of economic contacts will be discussed. In the second half of the 19th century, monetary stability and free trade created a truly global economy, but not without suppressing a substantial part of the  world. From 1914 on, two world wars and the Cold War prevented a complete recovery of economic relations. Political interests caused that national economies were created with relatively limited international contacts. In post-1945 Europe this was a problem. Not only had the 1930s shown that economic nationalism was fatal for growth and development, but Germany also was a problem. For these reasons European economic integration seemed a solution. Until the collapse of the Soviet Union, this proved very successful. In the 1990s liberalisation of international markets, but also, just as in the late 19th century, an enormous decline of transport costs, caused a second period of globalisation. Now multinational companies cut apart their production chains,  and each step was done wherever in the world is cheapest. Europe was no longer the centre and its process of integration, that after the Cold War got a boost, is now even crumbling.</body>

column1: The course starts with two general lectures on the question why we should be engaged with international and comparative research in criminology; how with the process of globalisation a so-called ‘global criminology’ has emerged; and point at some socio-historical and cultural factors that have determined why criminology developed differently in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. The key-question in this respect is whether concrete criminological questions can actually be addressed with theoretical models that pretend to have a global validity, but mostly have Western biases. Next we will follow the structure of Katja Franko her book, of which the central line is that globalisation and digitalization offers opportunities for certain people and indeed confronts others with new limitations and forms of social exclusion. Globalisation and digitalisation also come along with types of deviance, crime and crime control that take place across physical and digital borders. In this context, we deal with human trafficking, cybercrime, eco-crime and crimes against humanity. Additional readings offer a more concrete analysis of each of these issues, whereas guest-lecturers and practitioners will bridge the academic and the practical dimensions of the issues discussed.

In this course, we will discuss theories and empirical cases related to the contemporary functioning of art worlds and the dynamics of cultural globalisation and aesthetic appropriation which shape them. Arguably, cultural production and consumption have become more transnationally-oriented. We look at the changing relationship between cultural production and consumption and place; the networked nature of artistic production and consumption, and the social conventions that govern them. Students get acquainted with the major contemporary trends and developments in the visual arts, music and the media, drawing on case studies from Western and non-Western context.  This course will be conducted as seminar which foregrounds student discussion and analysis of the readings.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course aims to take a fresh look at the notion of art worlds and the socialized nature of artistic and cultural production and consumption à la Becker, in light of theories of and empirical research on cultural globalisation. Drawing on examples from contemporary art movements, the media and music industries from around the world, we look at how art worlds operate across spatial scales; and how trends and social conventions spread across the world; and how they become embedded in different places and social contexts.</body>

column1: Central to the seminar is cultural globalization: the global dispersion of (popular) cultural products. Cultural exchange transcending regions and nation-states is not a new phenomenon, but the past three decades witnessed an accelerated intensification of international cultural flows, thanks to much improved dissemination means (e.g. streaming and other digital technologies) and  transnationalisation in media and cultural-industry businesses.

Media are pivotal in this process of cultural globalization: all around the world, people are familiar with TV series such as The Big Bang Theory, the Marvel Cinematic Universe and popular music artists like Beyoncé. Globalization however, is not the same as Americanization: Indian movies, South Korean popular culture (K-wave) and formats such as The Voice are sold and consumed all over the world. In this course the meanings of developments in the media industries for production, content and consumption of media products is scrutinized. Due to their global presence entertainment genres form the focal point of this course. To critically examine cultural globalization in relation to media industries and the symbolic meanings produced the ‘critical political economy’ approach is adopted.

column1: During this course students will explore the multidimensional nature of the legal orders (a new development) that lawyers are confronted with in a globalized world. The focus will be on how various international and European Union legal orders, but also transnational legal orders (think e.g. of the Forest Stewardship Council wood certification scheme), inter-relate and how they relate to the values enshrined in national legal orders. The point of departure for the course will be how the internationalization and Europeanization of law relate to enhanced economic integration and interdependence (i.e. globalization) and may compromise values that are regarded as essential to law as developed in liberal legal orders. These essential values include those related to the rule of law, human rights and democracy. In other words, during the course, legal developments related to enhanced economic interdependence, often resulting in technocratic decision-making at international and European levels of decision making, will be problematized in an interdisciplinary context.

The course builds on the knowledge, insights and skills acquired during the course Research and Writing Skills (Block 1) in European Union, International Law and Global Governance (Block 2) and The Law and Policy of European Integration (Block 2) and in particular seeks to broaden the student’s knowledge of the processes already introduced in the previous courses and enhance his/her legal and research skills, both in writing and oral format.

The course is problem-based, in the sense that real-world issues/themes are the point of departure; it thus takes an inductive approach. That said, in considering these issues students will be prompted to master systemic critical analysis, integrating concepts which are essential components of the systems of International and European Union law.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Students completing this course will be able to independently:

column2: • Describe, analyze and critically assess new developments in international and European Union law and the causes thereof;
• Describe, analyze and critically assess the consequences of a multidimensional legal order, integrating the findings of other disciplines, in particular political science, sociology and economics;

• Engage in legal comparison and integration, that is comparing and integrating legal developments at an international and EU level in relation to each other and to legal values associated with national legal orders; and as a consequence:
• Conduct systemic, horizontal and vertical legal analysis;
• Develop, conduct and account for academic research on issues pertaining to globalization and multidimensional legal orders.
• Develop and present different types of legal advice on pertinent legal problems (taking into account ethical considerations), both orally and writing.
• Constructively engage in peer review and reflect on their own learning process.

column1: The so-called Islamic State recruits members from around the world for their cause through Twitter. Netflix recently declared that after analysing their browsing statistics, they realized that the old constructs of cultural taste in association with the usual suspects of gender, class and age are irrelevant in their algorithmic design. Solidarity marches are happening more frequently around the world –the Occupy movement, Women’s march, and March for Science. What these diverse phenomena are pointing out today is that we live in an increasingly global world where through social media, we are able to create new forms of communities, cultures and contexts that go beyond national borders.

Hence, it is worth asking: Is the notion of the nation state redundant? Does culture matter today in the age of the internet? As social networking sites and their impact spans across borders, are we living in a post-cultural age? To talk of global and representative practice, we need to expand our frames of reference, revisit sacred discourses and Western-biased rubrics of digital design and practice. A paradigm shift is needed in approaching cultural phenomena on the internet with a more global-oriented, open- ended and pluralistic perspective. This seminar investigates popular events, claims and trends by going into the history of dominant theories of influence over these decades including (post) structuralism, (post) modernism, (post) Marxism, feminism and (post)colonial discourse .This opens up critical discussions on key topics such as privacy/surveillance, labour/leisure, activism, democracy, and media consumption/production.  This is essential for students to be able to position their research and target audience within a more globally architected digital and cultural landscape.

Iedereen heeft te maken met goederenrecht, of het nu de vraag betreft wie eigendom van een gestolen fiets heeft of de vraag aan welke eisen een bank moet voldoen wil zij bewerkstelligen dat zij een geldig pandrecht krijgt op de handelsvorderingen van haar debiteur. Het goederenrecht is daarnaast onlosmakelijk verbonden met het insolventierecht. Denk aan vragen als, moet de curator van de dief van bovengenoemde gestolen fiets deze fiets ook in faillissement teruggeven, of moet de fiets juist ten behoeve van de gezamenlijke schuldeisers worden verkocht? column1: Think about the last time you shared a link with your friends and family. It could have been an informative article, a silly meme, or a song you like. Now think again, why did you share it with your family? Most likely, you weren't the only one who shared it, but part of a viral spread of information. The Going Viral: Ideas that Spread Around the World course will help you answer that question. We will explore why some things go viral while others never gain traction. In doing so, we'll examine the very specific conditions that social networks set. The course will cover not only the positive potential of viral information spread, but also the dangers that exponential spread of misinformation poses to society.

The cornerstones of the course are set by three influential books on word-of-mouth. In addition to sections from these seminal books, influential scholarly articles on the topic are discussed. These articles cover the broad spectrum of academic research in marketing, from basic psychology to memory and attention effects in consumer research to quantitative modeling of social networks and information diffusion. So not only will this course help you understand and design successful ideas and products, it will also provide a broad introduction to the rich field of marketing research by covering one of its core topics: Word-of-mouth.

column1: Healthcare managers increasingly are confronted with changes in the policy environment affecting the ways they organize and manage daily care processes. For example, legal requirements for patient participation force healthcare managers to install patient representatives in their advisory boards, and safety regulations ask for structured ways of organizing and accounting for the quality of care within healthcare organizations. Policy measures also influence the strategic choices of managers; if patient safety is displayed as an important problem in healthcare, rendering patient safety a top priority of the healthcare institution can be a valuable way of presenting the institution to third-party payers and patients.

Yet, incorporating national policy aims and measures in the organization’s policies also transforms the role of the healthcare organization. A healthcare organization is not a neutral adaptor of national policy requirements, but actively gives shape to these policies. For instance, what patient participation means and how the actual role of patients in the healthcare organization’s decision making process is fleshed out in practice, gets shape in the day-to-day interactions between health care managers, healthcare practitioners and quality staff.
This course aims to provide HCM students with theoretical lenses as well as practical knowledge to the understanding and dealing with governance and strategy issues in healthcare organizations.
Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch

column1: Het vak Governance in de zorg focust zich op de drie partijen in de zorg, de zorgaanbieder, de zorgverzekeraar en de patiënten(vereniging). Vanuit het rechtspersonenrecht wordt deze drie partijen nader belicht. Daarnaast maakt de student in het vak Governance in de zorg kennis met de zeer uiteenlopende relaties waarmee mensen aan deze zorgorganisaties verbonden (kunnen) zijn, variërend van hoogopgeleide, vrijgevestigde medisch specialisten tot uitzendkrachten werkzaam in de schoonmaak, van bestuurders, interne toezichtzichthouders tot leden van cliëntenraden en ondernemingsraden. Aandacht wordt besteed aan onder meer vraagstukken van governance, medezeggenschap en arbeidsrecht.

column1: <body>A cooperative consists of a society of members and an enterprise, where the former owns the latter. This course addresses the three sources of superior creation of value by a cooperative: the organization of the society of members, the transaction relationship between the society of members and the cooperative firm, and the commitment of the cooperative firm to certain competitive behavior due to it being owned by the society of members. Themes to be addressed are emergence of cooperatives; ownership of enterprise; multiple goals; incentives in cooperatives; membership stability and fair division; decision making in cooperatives; coordination and alignment in cooperatives; competitive strategy by cooperatives.</body>

column1: This course is coordinated by the Erasmus University Rotterdam and given jointly with University of Leiden, and Institute of Social Science, and is part of the Governance of Migration and Diversity Master programme.

This course offers a multidisciplinary outlook on governance of migration and diversity from the perspectives of public administration, history, sociology and development studies.  The course aims to stimulate a dialogue between the practice of migration and diversity governance and a variety of theoretical perspectives on governance. During the seminars and site-visits the students are given the opportunity to engage in discussions with both scholars and practitioners of governance.

The course consists of seminars and field trips (or webinars). It includes two introductory lectures about the structure of the course and about the foundations of  governance theory. The following eight sessions will be conducted by governance scholars working within disciplinary traditions of Public Administration, Sociology, History and Development Studies, each seminar introducing the topic and new aspects of governance theory will be followed up by a site visit  to the organizations, where students are expected to engage in conversation with practitioners of governance.
NB. Due to COVID-19 situation in the country, the visits to the sites may be replaced by webinars with practitioners from the organizations.</body>

column1: Cities are increasingly seen as important places to ‘govern’ health. In the Netherlands, cities have gained more responsibilities since the decentralizations of care and support to local municipalities. On the local level, solutions need to be found for pressing problems, such as rising health inequalities between neighbourhoods, fragmented public service provision, and unsuitable housing for aging populations. To address these problems in innovative ways, experiments are being conducted in urban labs and inter-sectoral networks are set-up to enhance collaboration between different stakeholders in the city.

In this course we explore the ways in which urban health has come to be governed in modern societies. Governance, in the literature as well as in practices, stands for policy without central policy actors. That is: policymaking and implementation have come to rest on a myriad of actors and perspectives that are interwoven in networks. The course therefore serves as a guide to how urban governance for health is being done. This will be discussed both on a theoretical level (using concepts) and on practical level (using urban action research).

During the course students will work together with a field partner in Rotterdam on a specific urban issue. This ‘action-research’ will allow students to delve deeper into an urban problem and propose policy recommendations for solving it. Grading is based on a group paper, where theoretical concepts and recommendations for practice come together, and on an individual open-questions exam.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The main objective of this course is for students to get acquainted with healthcare governance as a concept and the different shapes and forms of governance in practice. More specifically, the following learning goals apply to this course:

column2: • Students have an understanding of the shift from government to governance
• Students have an understanding of different coordination modes in governance (market, state, networks and communities)
• Students can explain the connection between place and healthcare governance.
• Students can apply theoretical concepts from the literature to analyze empirical cases of healthcare governance (see the 2 cases in Feijenoord, Rotterdam)
• Students will be able to develop useful policy recommendations for Feijenoord on the basis of the key concepts and themes of this course
• Students are able to explain and critically reflect on how people can be ‘responsibilized’ and be ‘made governable’
• Students are able to effectively discuss literature and issues on governance during meetings
• Students are able to provide peer-support to each other during workgroups by reading and discussing each other’s draft version of the report
• Students are able to write a coherent essay on the basis of a clear research question.

column1: When it comes to social inequalities, policies and institutional arrangements are part of the equation. They help shaping the incidence and consequences of our endowments and of the events we experience during our life – and often do so unequally. Policies and institutions may in fact mitigate social disparities, build some anew, magnify others, or even do all of the above at once. The result is often composite, a patchwork of trade-offs and unintended consequences cutting across the social fabric.

In this course we will examine a number of policies and institutional arrangements implicated in the (re)production of social inequalities. We will explore theory- and evidence- based accounts of these policies and institutions, of their features and effects as examined across the social sciences. Emphasis will be given to current debates, both academic and public, and to the organisation of informed debates within the class. Particular attention will be devoted, but by all means will not be limited, to the realms of welfare provision and labour markets. Most of all, the course will focus on four axes of social inequality, namely gender, generation and cohort, race and ethnicity, and class.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: <body>After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Review and analyse theory- and evidence-based accounts of the features and consequences of different policies and institutions, with a particular emphasis on the (re)production of social inequalities;
• Reflect on how policies and institutions respond to socio-economic, demographic, and political developments;

• Identify trade-offs and unintended consequences of policies and institutional arrangements, i.e. how policies and institutions might mitigate some social inequalities while simultaneously producing or intensifying others;
• Apply a theoretical “toolbox”, built on the insights of sociology and (equally) of other social sciences, to analyse policies/institutions and their consequences.

column1: After successful completion of this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Make informed policy recommendations, especially in the realm of social policies or other institutions implicated in social inequalities;
• Report and summarise findings in a clear and effective manner (in writing).

column1: Cities are dynamic engines of economies growth and innovation, but they also create negative externalities such as inequality, poverty and pollution. Urban economies are primarily coordinated by market transactions, many of which take place at an (inter)national level. The ability of urban governments to influence markets is limited and widely discussed. The course adopts a network governance perspective, debating if and how varying combinations of markets, state and non-state actors steer and facilitate local economic development. The question is if and how urban network governance can stimulate economic growth and innovation, while overcoming negative externalities.

The course first discusses multi-disciplinary factors driving economic growth, creativity, innovation and entrepreneurship in a global economy. Subsequently the section zooms in on transitions towards sustainable and resilient urban economies, responding to recent challenges such as climate change, financial crises, growing inequality and the Brexit.

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column2: • Distinguish and apply different perspectives to urban economic governance
• Analyze the complex nature of urban economic governance across and within sectors and cities
• Formulate conditions for sustainable and inclusive urban economic growth and inclusive innovation
• Determinate strategies to overcome negative externalities (like poverty, inequality and pollution)

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }

column1: Our world is facing multiple complex, uncertain and value-laden problems – including climate change, social injustices, loss of biodiversity to name a few. To address such problems, it is considered necessary that our societies change in structural and profound ways. Such long-term processes of structural change addressing persistent societal problems are referred to as societal transitions or transformations. Considering the emergent nature of societal transitions and their dynamics – the future remains plural and uncertain with many actors seeking to influence them; think of social movements such as Extinction Rebellion, local, regional, and national governments, non-governmental actors, but also big business and social enterprises, next to community groups. This course focuses specifically on the normative ideals of sustainability and justice as guiding ideas for actors seeking to actively explore, guide and accelerate ‘desirable’ societal dynamics. In doing so they are faced with key uncertainties characterized by climate breakdown, the dwindling influence of Western dominated global institutions, the rise of non-governmental influence and anti-establishment social movements, all during a new technological revolution which will see the rise of automation, artificial intelligence, and the dismantling of traditional labour-capital frameworks.

This course seeks to help you understand how actors make sense of this context of global destabilization and prepare for desirable futures. The two main questions tackled in the course are: (i) how we can make sense of/understand discourses and actions around just sustainability transitions, and (ii) what is the extent to which and how just sustainability transitions can be governed?  You will learn how you can contribute to debates about just sustainability transitions from different perspectives and how you can design a transition governance intervention. The governance of transitions arises from the agency of a diversity of actors involved in structural change and innovative action and their attempts to orchestrate the changes taking place at different levels. Hence, the keywords in this regard are scenario building, experimentation, learning, and reflexivity.

The teaching methods comprise lectures, classroom discussions and exercises, and individual and group work. The lectures and discussions are intended to give you a grounding in transition thinking, while the group work will allow you to design a transition governance intervention. The written examination will then focus on the lecture material on just sustainability transitions and their governance, whilst the group project examines your group work on designing a transition governance intervention on behalf of a private or public organisation (of your choice).</body>

column2: <style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
• Understand the basics of transition thinking and transition governance;
• Appraise and critically discuss ongoing societal developments from a transition perspective;
• Identify the main challenges and opportunities for governing transitions;
• Explain how societal actors seek to exert influence and the changing roles of institutions in guiding society through transitions;
• Distinguish different kinds of arguments (normative, empirical, etc) in discourses around justice and sustainability in the context of transformative change;
• Formulate coherent arguments about societal transition challenges (especially related to justice and sustainability) and how to tackle these;
• Design transition governance interventions relevant for private or public organisations.

column1: This course aims to further the following key competences for sustainability to different degrees: systems-thinking competence, anticipatory competence, normative competence, strategic competence, and interpersonal competence.</body>

column1: It is no coincidence that our psychology bachelor curriculum in Rotterdam begins with a course about people in groups (social psychology). Groups were central to the human past, are central to our present, and will continue to be central to the human future. To understand human behavior, we need to understand groups, because people live in groups, play in groups, and.... work and perform in groups.

As a Work and Organizational Psychologist, you will be faced with groups at work all the time: departments, project teams, discussion groups, boards, work teams, et cetera. Often, your involvement will be about improving groups and teams, about suggesting or implementing changes to make them more effective. In your future job you may, for example, design groups, build groups (or teams), advise groups, train groups, disband groups, address groups, motivate groups, study groups, or simply participate in groups.

By providing hands-on insight in and experience with state-of-the-art topics in the domain of groups at work, this course aims to prepare you for these and other intriguing encounters with the practice of groups at work.</body>

column1: The Grow module offers you a unique opportunity to build your knowledge, skills and experience in establishing and growing a business. The course deals with new business entry, expansion and scaling up, potentially, the exit of the founder-owner(s) of the business. Therefore, important topics are establishing the structure and governance of the nascent and growing firm, looking for its first sales and customers, finding critical resources (money, employees), and expanding the business. Eventually, some businesses may fail, some are wildly successful. Both scenarios might mean that the founders have plan for their exit and harvesting.

This BSc course is relevant for students who plan to become (or are already) involved in new venture formation, building fast-growing firms and making existing businesses more entrepreneurial. Students that want to know more about the ins and outs of start-ups, scale-ups and high-impact entrepreneurship as a future consultant to young and fast-growing companies, as an investor funding them, or as an entrepreneurship support manager (e.g., as a growth hacker) may find this course interesting and relevant too.

• whom to hire and how the roles and relationships should be created and managed,
• how to design the structure and create the culture of a growth-oriented venture.

column1: Human Resources have increasingly been recognised as a source of competitive advantage and as such good people management is vital for organisations. The course is designed to develop a thorough knowledge and understanding of the effective management of people. After exploring the theoretical origins of HRM, the emergence of HR strategy and the relationship between business strategy and HRM strategy, the course will focus on discussing and analysing important HRM activities such as HR planning, recruitment and selection, training and development, absence and retention management, reward and performance and exit management. A deepened understanding of the strategic character of these practical HRM activities provides students with the knowledge and skills required for the integration of HR policies into a coherent HRM strategy, the implementation of which will contribute to a high-performance organisation.

column1: This course offers students the opportunity to conduct an internship on a topic of their own interest. An internship can help students to apply their theoretical knowledge as well as develop their professional attitude including skills such as organizing, planning, analyzing data and professional collaboration with coworkers.

This course offers internships via two possible tracks; a practice-based and a research-based track. Students are themselves responsible for finding a practice-based internship, while we can place students interested in a research-based internship on an ongoing project of faculty. This can include a project that is offered by staff working on issues in human resources management, organizational change, organization theory and/or organizational behavior.

The duration of the internship is at least equivalent to 5-6 weeks full-time work, but can also be spread over a longer period of time or be conducted on a part-time basis. The research-based internship will most likely be part-time and the timeframe is determined in consultation with the staff. The planning of the practice-based internship depends on the organization involved.
Course starts in respective blocks with one plenary session and ends with a final presentation session. The course can be taken in Block 3,4 and 5.

column1: Macro principles of good writing and publishing (Day 1)
1.    What makes a paper a good paper; why do some paper get published and others not
3.    Writing as a contribution to scholarly discourse: Finding your conversation, finding a story to tell
4.    Structuring a paper: Different options and when they are appropriate.
6.    Knowing the key ingredients for each section of a paper: what has go into an introduction, a literature review, etc., and where exactly should it be located.
7.    Good sections, good paragraphing (pyramid principle, topic sentences etc.)
8.    Rules for building strong sentences, cohesion among sentences (e.g., relating to action characters, strong verbs, 2-3-1, paragraphing, creating overlap, from known to unknown, concision)
9.    Choice of tense and mode to fit section of the paper and the content, choice of words that send the right “signals”, etc.
10.    Conducting your writing project: Strategies for productive writing and editing
11.    Writing to get published in leading academic journals
14.    Measuring and managing your impact as a scholar
Prerequisites: Please note that attendance is expected on all three days. Participants will be admitted on a first come, first served basis. The maximum number of participants is 20.
